episodes.original_body:
Case: Shannon-Lankswert-WC-02-07-2025
Client: Shannon Lankswert

Friend working for UPS - 3rd Shift Fueler - Went to bathroom in Fuel Yard - Fell down metal stairs on her way out - Struck back & both arms/elbows on the way down stairs - Employer transported to Concentra - Advised of Back & Arm injury - Concentra checked arm & took xrays - Ignored Back Injury - Provided "work as tolerated" Note - Client followed up with Flaget Memorial when pain had not subsided - Placed off work at least Until 02.13 - Client returned to Concentra for PT 02/13 - Concentra advised Client that they are 'Not allowed by Law to place off work due to Account with UPS' - Concentra gave work restrictions - UPS unable to accommodate Restrictions - Forcing Client to use Vacation Time & PTO instead of initiating WC Claim - Client has been off work since DOI - Advised UPS should have initiated WC Claim once off work more than 3 days - Client is not sure how to proceed - Advised will send Intake Packet & mark as Hold until she decides if she wants us fully involved - Client appreciated the information & would like Intake Packet emailed to her
episodes.natural_language:
Case Shannon-Lankswert-WC-02-07-2025 involves the client, Shannon Lankswert. The record describes an incident involving a friend of the client who works for UPS as a 3rd shift fueler. This friend went to the bathroom in a fuel yard and fell down metal stairs on her way out, striking her back and both arms/elbows during the descent. The employer transported her to Concentra, where she was advised of back and arm injuries. Concentra checked the arm and took X-rays but reportedly ignored the back injury and issued a "work as tolerated" note.

The client followed up with Flaget Memorial when the pain had not subsided and was placed off work at least until 02/13. On 02/13, the client returned to Concentra for physical therapy. Concentra advised the client that they are 'Not allowed by Law to place off work due to Account with UPS.' Concentra provided work restrictions, but UPS was unable to accommodate the restrictions, effectively forcing the client to use vacation time and PTO instead of initiating a workers’ compensation claim. The client has been off work since the date of injury (DOI). It was advised that UPS should have initiated a workers’ compensation claim once off work for more than 3 days. The client is not sure how to proceed. I advised that an Intake Packet would be sent and the case marked on hold until she decides whether she wants us to be fully involved. The client appreciated the information and requested that the Intake Packet be emailed to her.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

episodes.original_body:
Case: Shannon-Lankswert-WC-02-07-2025
Client: Shannon Lankswert

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Client attended PT w/Concentra - Concentra advised that due to 'account w/UPS' they are 'not allowed to place off work by law' but would provide restrictions
Client presented restriction to supervisor - Advised still in too much pain to work - Supervisor advised that she has to start using Vacation/PTO to keep benefits 

Neither of these statement sit well with Client - Does not feel she should lose Vacation/PTO for WC injury - Asked if they provided WC information yet - Should have been provided after off work more then 3 days - Client advised that they have not mentioned WC one time - Client does not feel she is able to return to full duty yet - Still painful to sit for long period (Drives a Fueling Truck) - Supervisor can not accommodate restrictions but wants Client to still come in though there is no work available for her 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: February 13 2025
episodes.natural_language:
Case Shannon-Lankswert-WC-02-07-2025. Initial client contact on February 13, 2025 was with Sarena regarding Shannon Lankswert’s workers’ compensation case and current work status.

The client attended physical therapy with Concentra. Concentra advised that, due to an account with UPS, they are not allowed by law to place someone off work, but they would provide restrictions.

The client presented these restrictions to her supervisor, who advised that she would need to start using Vacation/PTO to keep her benefits.

Neither of these statements sits well with the client. She does not feel she should lose Vacation/PTO for a workers’ compensation injury. She asked whether they had provided workers’ compensation information yet, noting that it should have been provided after being off work for more than three days. The client reports that WC information has not been mentioned at all. She does not feel she is able to return to full duty yet and remains in pain when sitting for long periods, as she drives a fueling truck. The supervisor cannot accommodate the restrictions but still wants the client to come in, even though there is no work available for her.

Case: Shannon-Lankswert-WC-02-07-2025
Client: Shannon Lankswert

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ S/w Client - Employer still pushing her to come into work even though they are unable to accommodate restrictions - WC Claim still not established to her knowledge - Been off work over a week now - Advised Client WC should have been established once she missed 3 days of work - UPS attempting to avoid reporting injury - Advised Client she should obtain representation as UPS tends to pull this often (not report injuries & try to circumvent WC process, will make Client waste Vacation/PTO until Client is back in financial corner) - Client Requested Intake as she would like help getting claim properly set up & monitored - Sent WC Intake via DocuSign 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: February 17 2025
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on February 17, 2025, with Shannon Lankswert regarding a workers’ compensation matter. Sarena made the contact. The client reports that her employer is continuing to push her to come into work even though they are unable to accommodate her restrictions, and she says the WC claim has not been established to her knowledge. She has been off work for over a week. She was advised that workers’ compensation should have been established once she missed 3 days of work. She also states that UPS is attempting to avoid reporting the injury.

She was advised to obtain representation, as UPS tends to engage in practices that do not report injuries and attempt to circumvent the WC process, which could result in the client wasting vacation/PTO until she is back in a financially precarious position. The client requested intake assistance as she would like help getting the claim properly set up and monitored. A WC Intake form was sent via DocuSign.

Tuttle, with the same title and firm details as above, including the address, direct line, main line with extension, and email address (PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS). Case: Shannon-Lankswert-WC-02-07-2025
Client: Shannon Lankswert

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd Client Intake back - Completed Set Up - Sent Turn Over Ltr to Employer - Provided Copy to Client as well

Completed Intro Call - Client still in pain - Called In last night

Client states Supervisor has advised that they can not accommodate restrictions - Client mentioned another employee who is also injured & they are unable to accommodate, so they make employee sit in breakroom for 8 hours - Client is not comfortable with this as it is difficult to sit for long period & chairs are not padded - Advised Client to make the best of it & if it is unbearable, be sure to report & update supervisor - Also advised Client to take photo of chairs if placed in breakroom for the evening - Advised Client we would locate provider near her as she has right to chose provider - Concentra advised Client that due to their account with UPS they are not legally allowed to place the Client off work

Advanced Injury & Rehab in Bardstown accepts WC - Has opening for tomorrow (weather permitting) - If not they will see Client for sure on Thursday at 2p - Sent Appt Info to Client via Text 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: February 18 2025
episodes.natural_language:
Case Shannon-Lankswert-WC-02-07-2025 involves client Shannon Lankswert. On February 18 2025, Sarena made contact regarding the case. The client intake was received, setup completed, a turnover letter was sent to the employer, and a copy was provided to the client.

An introductory call was completed; the client remains in pain and had called in last night. The client states that her supervisor advised they cannot accommodate her restrictions. She cited another injured employee who is also not accommodated, with that employee made to sit in the breakroom for eight hours. The client is not comfortable with this arrangement, as sitting for long periods is difficult and the breakroom chairs are not padded. She was advised to make the best of it and, if it becomes unbearable, to report it and update the supervisor. She was also advised to photograph the chairs if they are placed in the breakroom for the evening. Additionally, she was advised that we would locate a provider near her, since she has the right to choose a provider. Concentra advised the client that, due to their account with UPS, they are not legally allowed to place the client off work.

Advanced Injury & Rehab in Bardstown accepts workers’ compensation and has an opening for tomorrow, weather permitting; if not, they will certainly see the client on Thursday at 2:00 p.m. Appointment information was sent to the client via text.

This contact was made by Sarena on February 18 2025.

episodes.natural_language:
This narrative summarizes the communications in Shannon Lankswert’s workers’ compensation case, identified as Shannon-Lankswert-WC-02-07-2025 and file WC80D-H07503. The Whaley Law Firm, representing Shannon, notified her on February 20, 2025, that a new workers’ compensation adjuster, Kaitlin Ericksen, had been assigned to Shannon’s claim. The firm instructed Shannon not to speak with Ms. Ericksen, Mr. Stewart, or any other individuals who may reach out to her, and to refer all such inquiries back to the Whaley Law Firm for further assistance. They advised that the carrier has been provided with all documentation Shannon had supplied, and they had completed a Kentucky Department of Workers Claims (KY DWC) Form 114 for travel reimbursement for Shannon’s appointment up to that date. Shannon was asked to keep the firm posted after each of her visits so that Form 114 reimbursements could continue, and to contact the firm directly with any questions.

In a forwarded message dated February 20, 2025, at 11:16 AM, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm addressed Kaitlin Ericksen and copied Bryce Koon. She stated that the firm was attaching their office’s letter of representation, KY DWC Form 106, KY DWC Form 113, and KY DWC Form 114 for the related claim, along with injury photos and scene photos for the file. Ms. Lankswert had an appointment that afternoon at 2:00 PM with Advanced Injury Rehab for further evaluation of her injuries. Tuttle explained that UPS had delayed processing the claim, and Shannon’s immediate supervisor had informed her that they could not accommodate the restrictions set by Concentra; however, she was still required to drive more than 35 miles to the property and to sit in a breakroom for the evening. Because of her injuries, Shannon had been advised not to drive long distances and could not sit in the provided chairs, as evidenced by photos. These circumstances led Shannon to use vacation time and to incur occurrences for missed time. The firm requested that TTD (Temporary Total Disability) benefits be processed as soon as possible and asked that Shannon’s vacation time and Attendance Status be reinstated promptly to prevent future issues. They emphasized that Shannon should not have accrued any occurrences or been punished for her work-related injury. The message concluded with an invitation to contact the firm with any questions and expressed a hope for an amicable resolution.

Earlier that same day, on February 20, 2025, at 10:36 AM, Kaitlin Ericksen, a Claims Specialist II with Liberty Mutual Insurance, wrote to Shannon. She introduced herself as the adjuster assigned to Shannon Lankswert’s workers’ compensation claim and invited Shannon to reach out if she needed anything. Ericksen’s signature block included her contact information: Liberty Mutual Insurance, Indianapolis, IN; Office: 317-483-8037; Fax: 603-422-6845; Mailing Address: P.O. Box 7170, Indianapolis, IN 46207. The email also contained standard confidentiality and privilege notices, stating that the information in the email and any attachments is confidential and may be privileged or constitute attorney work product, and provided instructions for unintended recipients to notify the sender, refrain from using or disseminating the content, and destroy copies. A privacy notice was also referenced via a Privacy Policy website link.

Overall, the communications document the case’s status as of February 20, 2025, including the assignment of a new adjuster, the exchange of representation documents and forms (106, 113, 114), upcoming medical evaluation, travel reimbursement considerations, work restrictions challenges, vacation-time implications, and the stated aim to initiate benefits and rectify attendance records promptly, all within the context of ongoing attempts to achieve an amicable resolution.

On February 20, 2025, Liberty Mutual claims staff exchanged information regarding Shannon Lankswert’s workers’ compensation claim (WC80D-H07503). Kaitlin Ericksen, a Claims Specialist II in the Workers’ Compensation Claims group in Indianapolis, informed Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm that UPS could accommodate the restrictions provided, and that there was no driving restriction in writing. She also stated that Liberty Mutual could not pay temporary total disability (TTD) benefits at that time, because it appeared there was work available within Ms. Lankswert’s restrictions.

Earlier that same day, at 10:17 AM, Sarena Tuttle sent a response with attachments and additional details. She noted that the office’s letter of representation and Kentucky Department of Workers’ Claims forms KY DWC Form 106, 113, and 114 for the related claim were attached, along with injury photos and scene photos. Ms. Lankswert was scheduled for an appointment this afternoon at 2:00 PM with Advanced Injury Rehab for further evaluation of her injuries. Tuttle explained that UPS had delayed processing this claim, and that Ms. Lankswert had been advised by her immediate supervisor that they could not accommodate the restrictions set by Concentra; nonetheless, she remained required to drive more than 35 miles to the property and to sit in a breakroom for the evening. Because of her injuries, she was advised not to drive for long periods and could not sit in the chairs provided, as shown in the photos. This situation had forced Ms. Lankswert to use vacation time and accrue occurrences for the time she missed. Tuttle urged immediate processing of her TTD benefits and asked that Liberty Mutual reinstate Ms. Lankswert’s vacation time and attendance status as soon as possible to avoid future issues, stressing that she should not have accrued any occurrences or been punished for the work-related injury. She invited any questions and expressed a desire to work toward an amicable resolution.

Also on February 20, 2025, Kaitlin Ericksen sent a follow-up note clarifying that she is the adjuster assigned to Shannon Lankswert’s workers’ compensation claim and inviting the recipient to reach out if anything else was needed. This message preceded and complemented the detailed update regarding accommodations, restrictions, and the need to timely process TTD benefits and correct attendance records.

The communications include standard confidentiality and privilege notices typical of the claims correspondence, and they reference the case details, the related Kentucky workers’ claim forms and attachments, as well as photos documenting Ms. Lankswert’s injuries and scene, all tied to the WC80D-H07503 claim.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Shannon-Lankswert-WC-02-07-2025. Client: Shannon Lankswert. Re: Re: WC80D-H07503 Shannon Lankswert.

The record begins with an email chain dated February 20, 2025, in which Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, wrote to Kaitlin Ericksen, a Claims Specialist II for Liberty Mutual Insurance, with Bryce Koon copied. In her message, tittle-fast The Whaley Law Firm argued that Ms. Lankswert should be compensated from the date of the incident through her release back to full duty. Tuttle noted that Ms. Lankswert is a Fuel Truck Driver, a role that requires sitting for long periods, lifting hoses that weigh more than 10 pounds, and climbing stairs, all of which contribute to pain and delay recovery. She asserted that Concentra has placed restrictions on Ms. Lankswert instead of authorizing time off because Concentra has a standing order from UPS not to place their employees off work, a policy Tuttle described as unethical. According to the message, Ms. Lankswert cannot drive because she cannot sit for long periods, cannot lift the hoses, and cannot repeatedly climb stairs; these restrictions were listed in documents provided to the adjuster earlier that day. The restrictions enumerated by Concentra were: the ability to lift up to 10 pounds, the ability to push/pull up to 10 pounds, bending occasionally (defined as up to 3 hours per day for a full-time Fueler, where bending is a constant requirement for entering and exiting the truck), occasional trunk rotation (also up to 3 hours per day, a constant requirement for fueling), alternating sitting and standing for pain control (which could not be maintained if actively fueling), no squatting, kneeling, or climbing ladders (ladders are needed to enter planes to check fuel levels and connect/disconnect hoses). Tuttle stated that UPS, via Ms. Lankswert’s immediate supervisor Amy Roy, advised that they cannot accommodate these restrictions and instructed Ms. Lankswert to sit in the breakroom all evening. She emphasized that sitting in the breakroom does not constitute accommodation and can cause harm and pain to a person with a tailbone injury documented in Flaget Records. The message also noted that Ms. Lankswert has chosen to move her medical treatment to an unbiased provider and would have updated documents later that afternoon. Finally, Tuttle argued that Temporary Total Disability (TTD) should be issued for time already missed, that occurrences should be removed from her attendance file due to UPS’s strict attendance policy, and that termination could occur if an employee exhausts all available occurrences.

The email from Kaitlin Ericksen responding to this point was sent later the same day, February 20, 2025, at approximately 12:33 PM. Ericksen stated that UPS is able to accommodate the restrictions provided and that she did not see any driving restriction in writing. She concluded that, at that time, TTD could not be paid because it appeared there was work available within Ms. Lankswert’s restrictions.

Earlier in the day, at 10:17 AM, a separate email from Sarena Tuttle to Kaitlin Ericksen (with Bryce Koon cc’d) extended further documentation and context. Tuttle attached the office’s letter of representation along with Kentucky Department of Workers’ Claims (KY DWC) Forms 106, 113, and 114 for the related claim, as well as injury photos and scene photos. She noted that Ms. Lankswert had an appointment that afternoon at 2:00 PM with Advanced Injury Rehab for further evaluation of her injuries. Tuttle stated that UPS had delayed processing of the claim and that Ms. Lankswert’s immediate supervisor advised that they could not accommodate the restrictions but required her to drive more than 35 miles to the property and sit in a breakroom for the evening. She described that, due to her injuries, Ms. Lankswert had been advised not to drive for long periods and could not sit in the chairs provided, with photos supporting this claim. As a result, Ms. Lankswert had to use vacation time and would receive occurrences for the time missed. Tuttle urged that processing of Ms. Lankswert’s TTD benefits begin as soon as possible and requested that UPS reinstate Ms. Lankswert’s vacation time and attendance status to avoid future issues. She asserted that Ms. Lankswert should not have accrued any occurrences or been penalized for a work-related injury, and she welcomed any questions while expressing a desire to work toward an amicable resolution.

Additionally, the same thread includes an earlier message from Kaitlin Ericksen dated February 20, 2025, at 10:36 AM, in which she introduced herself as the adjuster assigned to Shannon Lankswert’s workers’ compensation claim and invited contact if anything was needed.

The messages include standard confidentiality and privilege notices typical of Liberty Mutual communications, reminding recipients to contact the sender if they are not the intended recipient, to refrain from disseminating the message or attachments, and to consult the company’s privacy notice. The record also shows the parties and contact information: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with Sarena M. Tuttle’s direct line and email address provided, and Liberty Mutual’s Indianapolis, Indiana office contact details for Kaitlin Ericksen.

In sum, the communications document a dispute over appropriate compensation and time loss following a tailbone injury for a fuel truck driver, the restrictions imposed by Concentra and UPS, the alleged lack of accommodation, and requests for TTD processing and removal of attendance occurrences, all within the context of a claim identified as WC80D-H07503 and the case Shannon Lankswert.

On February 20, 2025, in the case Shannon-Lankswert-WC-02-07-2025 (Re: Re: WC80D-H07503 Shannon Lankswert), Liberty Mutual Insurance and The Whaley Law Firm exchanged a series of emails concerning Shannon Lankswert’s workers’ compensation claim. The client, Shannon Lankswert, is described in the communications as a Fuel Truck Driver. The subject line shows the matter as Re: Re: WC80D-H07503 Shannon Lankswert and the participants included Kaitlin Ericksen, a Claims Specialist II with Liberty Mutual, and Sarena Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm.

Earlier in the day, at 10:17 AM, Sarena Tuttle sent an email with the office’s letter of representation for Ms. Lankswert along with KY DWC Forms 106, 113, and 114, plus injury and scene photos for the file. She noted that Ms. Lankswert had an appointment that afternoon at 2:00 PM with Advanced Injury Rehab for further evaluation of her injuries. She stated that UPS had apparently delayed arranging accommodations by Concentra, and that Shannon’s immediate supervisor had advised that UPS could not accommodate her restrictions. According to Sarena, Shannon is required to drive more than 35 miles to the property and to sit in a breakroom for the evening, which she argued was not an accommodation of her restrictions. She described Shannon’s tailbone injury as documented in Flaget Records and stated Shannon had been advised not to drive for long periods and could not sit in the chairs provided (photos were submitted). Sarena asserted that Shannon had to use vacation time and was accruing “occurrences” under UPS’s attendance policy and risked termination for using all available occurrences. She requested that TTD (temporary total disability) benefits be issued for the time Shannon missed and asked that Shannon’s vacation time and attendance status be reinstated to avoid future issues. She also asked for any necessary steps to begin processing TTD benefits promptly and to remove the occurrences from Shannon’s attendance file. The email included Sarena’s contact information and noted a new email address for her.

Earlier still, at 10:36 AM, Kaitlin Ericksen, the Liberty Mutual adjuster assigned to Shannon’s claim, replied briefly to say she was the adjuster on the case and invited the Whaley Law Firm to let her know if anything was needed.

At 12:33 PM, Kaitlin sent another message indicating that UPS could accommodate the restrictions provided and that there did not appear to be any driving restriction in writing. Based on that, she stated that TTD could not be paid at that time because there was work available within Shannon’s restrictions.

At 1:44 PM, Sarena responded to Kaitlin with a detailed restatement of Shannon’s restrictions and the situation. She reiterated that Shannon should be compensated appropriately from the date of the incident until she is released back to full duty. She reiterated Shannon’s job duties as a Fuel Truck Driver, which require long periods of sitting, lifting hoses that weigh more than 10 pounds, and climbing stairs, all of which contribute to pain and delay recovery. She described Concentra as having placed restrictions rather than authorizing off-work status, allegedly due to a standing order from UPS (characterized by Sarena as unethical). She enumerated Shannon’s restrictions:

- May lift up to 10 pounds (hoses weigh more than 10 pounds).
- May push/pull up to 10 pounds (hoses weigh more than 10 pounds).
- May bend occasionally (up to 3 hours per day; as a full-time Fueler, bending is a constant requirement for getting in and out of the truck).
- May engage in trunk rotation occasionally (up to 3 hours per day; again a constant required activity for a Fueler).
- Will need to alternate sitting and standing for pain control (cannot alternate as needed if actively fueling).
- No squatting, kneeling, or climbing ladders (ladders are required to enter planes to check fuel levels and connect/disconnect hoses).

She added that UPS, via Shannon’s immediate supervisor Amy Roy, had advised they could not accommodate the restrictions and that Shannon was to sit in the breakroom all evening. This, she argued, was not a true accommodation and caused harm/pain to the injured party, consistent with the tailbone injury documented in the medical records. Shannon had chosen to pursue medical treatment with an unbiased provider and would provide updated documents later that afternoon. Sarena asserted that TTD should be issued for the time Shannon had already missed and that the occurrences should be removed from Shannon’s attendance file given UPS’s strict attendance policy. She urged beginning processing of Shannon’s TTD benefits and asked for Shannon’s vacation time and attendance status to be reinstated to prevent further issues, stating that Shannon should not have accrued any occurrences or been punished for a work-related injury. The email closed with Sarena’s signature and her firm’s contact details.

Later that same day, Kaitlin replied at 20:54:46 UTC, stating that UPS had confirmed suitable light-duty work was available and that, accordingly, TTD benefits would not be issued at that time.

Across the message thread, the email confidentiality notices and standard disclaimers were included by both parties, with frequent references to the confidential nature of the information and the privacy notices on Liberty Mutual’s and The Whaley Law Firm’s communications. The chain also included standard firm signatures, and repeated contact details for both Kaitlin Ericksen and Sarena Tuttle, as well as references to the documents and photos being provided for the file.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Shannon-Lankswert-WC-02-07-2025. Client: Shannon Lankswert. Re: Re: Re: WC80D-H07503 Shannon Lankswert. The Whaley Law Firm’s litigation team, led by Sarena M. Tuttle, is handling a workers’ compensation matter identified as WC80D-H07503 for Shannon Lankswert, with communications between Ms. Tuttle and Liberty Mutual Claims Specialist Kaitlin Ericksen regarding temporary total disability (TTD) benefits, work restrictions, and related delays.

On February 20, 2025, Ms. Tuttle forwarded a detailed update in the external matter. She explained that Shannon Lankswert had missed days due to her injury and that UPS had not provided suitable light‑duty work. Ms. Tuttle requested that TTD benefits be backdated to the date of Shannon’s incident to cover the days she could not work. She noted that Flaget Memorial had placed Shannon off work for a minimum of three days, from February 11 to February 14, 2025, and that Shannon had been placed off work indefinitely as of that afternoon. An attached Work Statement from Advanced Injury Rehab was referenced, and Ms. Tuttle urged Liberty Mutual to initiate the requested TTD benefits. She also stated that if the carrier refused to provide the benefits required by Kentucky state law, the file should be forwarded to legal counsel to avoid further delays, emphasizing that the claim had already been intentionally delayed by almost two weeks.

Earlier in the day, Kaitlin Ericksen of Liberty Mutual had communicated that UPS had confirmed suitable light‑duty work was available, and accordingly, TTD benefits would not be issued at that time. Ms. Tuttle subsequently responded with a more detailed description of Shannon’s restrictions and the impact on her ability to work.

At 10:17 AM, Ms. Tuttle sent an email attaching the firm’s representation letter and Kentucky Division of Workers’ Claims forms 106, 113, and 114, along with injury and scene photos for Shannon’s file. She noted that Shannon had a 2:00 PM appointment that afternoon with Advanced Injury Rehab for further evaluation of her injuries. She also indicated that UPS had delayed processing of the claim and that Shannon’s immediate supervisor had advised that the restrictions provided by Concentra could not be accommodated; Shannon would be required to drive more than 35 miles to the property and sit in a breakroom for the evening. Ms. Tuttle emphasized that Shannon’s tailbone injury was documented in Flaget Records and that Shannon had elected to pursue treatment with an unbiased provider, with updated documents to be provided later that afternoon. She urged that TTD be issued for the time Shannon had already missed and requested removal of occurrences from her attendance file due to UPS’s attendance policy.

At 12:33 PM, Kaitlin Ericksen replied that UPS could accommodate the restrictions provided and that there was no driving restriction in writing. Based on this, she stated that TTD could not be paid at that time, as there was work available within Shannon’s restrictions.

At 1:44 PM, Sarena Tuttle responded again to Kaitlin, detailing Shannon’s restrictions and the practical implications for her job as a Fuel Truck Driver. The posted restrictions included: lifting up to 10 pounds (hoses weigh more than 10 pounds); pushing/pulling up to 10 pounds (hoses weigh more than 10 pounds); bending occasionally (up to 3 hours per day, as a full‑time Fueler bending is a constant requirement); engaging in trunk rotation occasionally (up to 3 hours per day, also a constant requirement for fueling); alternating sitting and standing for pain control (which would be difficult while actively fueling); no squatting, kneeling, or climbing ladders (ladders are required to enter planes to check fuel levels and to connect/disconnect hoses). She also noted that UPS, through Shannon’s immediate supervisor Amy Roy, had advised they could not accommodate Shannon’s restrictions and instructed her to sit in the breakroom all evening. Ms. Tuttle stated that Shannon had chosen to move her medical treatment to an unbiased provider and anticipated updated documentation that afternoon. She reiterated that TTD should be issued for time missed and that the occurrences should be removed from Shannon’s attendance file due to UPS’s strict attendance policy and potential termination for using all available occurrences.

Kaitlin Ericksen followed up at 3:54 PM stating that UPS would be able to accommodate the restrictions and that there was no driving restriction in writing. Consequently, she advised that TTD would not be paid at that time because work was available within Shannon’s restrictions.

In the final message of the day, at 5:55 PM, Sarena Tuttle addressed Kaitlin directly with a pointed summary. She explained that Shannon had missed days due to her injury and that UPS could not provide suitable light‑duty work. She requested that TTD benefits be backdated to Shannon’s incident date to cover the days she was unable to work and noted that Flaget Memorial had placed Shannon off work for at least three days (February 11–14, 2025) and that Shannon remained off work indefinitely as of that afternoon. Ms. Tuttle attached the Work Statement from Advanced Injury Rehab and reiterated the need to initiate TTD benefits that had been requested three times. She warned that if Liberty Mutual continued to refuse the eligible benefits required by Kentucky state law, the file should be forwarded to Liberty Mutual’s legal counsel to avoid further delays, asserting that Shannon’s claim had already been delayed almost two weeks and that such delays were unacceptable.

Throughout the correspondence, the parties referenced Shannon’s tailbone injury, the restrictions provided to UPS, the involvement of Concentra, and the ongoing tension between accommodation of restrictions and the payment of TTD. The case file includes a letter of representation, Kentucky DWC Forms 106, 113, and 114, injury and scene photos, and documentation of Shannon’s appointment with Advanced Injury Rehab, with ongoing efforts to obtain timely and compliant TTD benefits under Kentucky law.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Shannon-Lankswert-WC-02-07-2025. Client: Shannon Lankswert.

On February 25, 2025, The Whaley Law Firm, via Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager Sarena M. Tuttle, sent Kaitlin Ericksen of Liberty Mutual an email with attachments containing certified medical records from Concentra and Flaget Memorial Hospital related to Mrs. Lankswert’s injuries. The message noted that Liberty Mutual had not yet responded to the firm’s February 20, 2025 correspondence concerning Mrs. Lankswert’s temporary total disability (TTD) benefits and/or Form 114 reimbursements. In reviewing the Concentra records, the firm observed that the wrong job description had been provided to Concentra: the records list Mrs. Lankswert’s job title as “Air Handler,” and the restrictions were based on that description. The email asked Liberty Mutual to confirm that the file reflects the correct job title of “Full Time Fueler,” explaining that these are two very different roles and that the restrictions tied to the Air Handler description do not permit Mrs. Lankswert to perform the duties of a Full Time Fueler. The note also explained that the two departments are separate, and Mrs. Lankswert’s immediate supervisor cannot accommodate the restrictions provided by Concentra. Nevertheless, Mrs. Lankswert was placed off work on February 20 for an indefinite period, presumably at least until her next evaluation. The email requested an immediate update on the status of her claim and provided Sarena Tuttle’s contact information, including her new email address.

Earlier that week, on February 20, 2025, at approximately 5:55 PM, Sarena Tuttle wrote Kaitlin Ericksen to report that Mrs. Lankswert had missed days due to her injury and that UPS could not provide suitable light-duty work. Tuttle stated that Mrs. Lankswert’s TTD payments should be backdated to the date of the incident to cover the days she was unable to work. She noted that Flaget Memorial had placed Mrs. Lankswert off work for a minimum of three days, from February 11 to February 14, 2025, and that Mrs. Lankswert had been placed off work indefinitely as of that afternoon. Tuttle attached a Work Statement from Advanced Injury Rehab and urged initiating TTD benefits, which she stated had been requested three times. She warned that if Liberty Mutual continued to refuse the eligible benefits required by Kentucky state law, the file should be forwarded to Liberty Mutual’s legal counsel to avoid further delays. She concluded by saying that the claim had already been intentionally delayed nearly two weeks and that this was unacceptable.

Earlier still, at 12:33 PM on February 20, 2025, Kaitlin Ericksen replied that UPS had stated they could accommodate the restrictions and that there was no driving restriction in writing. Based on this, she said Liberty Mutual could not pay TTD at that time because there was work available within Mrs. Lankswert’s restrictions.

At 1:44 PM on February 20, 2025, Sarena Tuttle sent a more detailed message to Kaitlin Ericksen (cc’ing Bryce Koon) under the subject line indicated in the thread. She argued that Mrs. Lankswert should be compensated from the date of the incident until she is released back to full duty. She explained that Mrs. Lankswert is a Fuel Truck Driver, which requires sitting for long periods, lifting heavy hoses, and climbing stairs—activities that cause additional pain and delay her recovery. She criticized Concentra for providing restrictions based on a description that did not match her actual job duties and asserted that UPS, via Mrs. Lankswert’s immediate supervisor, Amy Roy, had advised that they could not accommodate the restrictions and instructed her to sit in the breakroom. Tuttle contended that sitting in a breakroom does not constitute an accommodation and noted that Mrs. Lankswert had begun medical treatment with an unbiased provider, with updated documents expected later that afternoon. She argued that TTD should be issued for the time already missed and that occurrences should be removed from Mrs. Lankswert’s attendance file due to UPS’s strict attendance policy and the risk of termination for using all available occurrences. She also stated that Liberty Mutual should not delay benefits any further and pressed for timely action.

That same afternoon, at about 3:54 PM, Kaitlin Ericksen replied that UPS had confirmed suitable light-duty work was available, and therefore Liberty Mutual would not be issuing TTD benefits at that time.

Then, at approximately 5:55 PM on February 20, 2025, Sarena Tuttle sent a follow-up message reiterating the earlier points: Ms. Lankswert had missed days because of her injury, UPS could not provide suitable light-duty work, and her TTD payments should be backdated to the incident date to cover the days she could not work. She reiterated that Flaget Memorial had placed Ms. Lankswert off work for a minimum of three days (February 11–14, 2025) and that she had been placed off work indefinitely as of that afternoon. She again attached the Work Statement from Advanced Injury Rehab and requested the initiation of TTD benefits, noting the multiple requests to do so and urging immediate action. She stated that if the eligible benefits required by Kentucky state law were still being refused, the file should be forwarded to Liberty Mutual’s legal counsel to avoid further delays and emphasized that the claim had already been intentionally delayed for nearly two weeks, which she deemed unacceptable.

This note also includes the sender’s and recipients’ contact details, including Sarena M. Tuttle’s role as Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, and the new email address she referenced in her signature.

episodes.natural_language:
In late February 2025, the case of Shannon Lankswert (WC80D-H07503) was the subject of a series of email exchanges between Kaitlin Ericksen, a claims specialist with Liberty Mutual, and Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager with The Whaley Law Firm, regarding Shannon’s eligibility for temporary total disability (TTD) benefits, the appropriate job title and restrictions, and the status of medical records. The exchanges also involved Shannon’s drivers’ obligations and evidence from Concentra and Flaget Memorial Hospital, with a note that Shannon’s claim file includes a request to issue TTD benefits and reimburse Form 114.

On February 20, 2025, Sarena Tuttle sent an email in the afternoon attaching certified medical records from Concentra and Flaget Memorial Hospital related to Mrs. Lankswert’s injuries. She noted that they had not yet received a response to their February 20 correspondence concerning TTD benefits and Form 114 reimbursements. In the body of her message, she highlighted a discrepancy in the medical records: Concentra’s files indicated a job title of “Air Handler” and restricted duties based on that description, whereas she requested confirmation that Liberty Mutual’s file reflects the correct title of “Full Time Fueler.” Tuttle explained that “Air Handler” and “Full Time Fueler” describe two very different roles, and the restrictions aligned with an Air Handler would not permit the duties of a Full Time Fueler, while the two departments were separate and Shannon’s immediate supervisor could not accommodate the stated restrictions. She noted Shannon had been off work starting February 20 for an indefinite period (at least until Shannon’s next evaluation), and she requested an immediate status update on the claim.

Earlier that same day, at 1:44 PM, Tuttle had written that Shannon’s claim had involved Miss Lankswert missing days due to the injury and that UPS could not provide suitable light-duty work. Tuttle asserted that Shannon’s TTD payments should be backdated to the incident date to cover the days she was unable to work, and she referenced Flaget Memorial’s placement of Shannon off work for a minimum of three days (February 11–14, 2025). She stated that Shannon had been placed off work indefinitely as of that afternoon and attached a Work Statement from Advanced Injury Rehab. Tuttle urged Liberty Mutual to initiate TTD benefits (which she indicated had been requested three times already) and warned that if the carrier refused to provide benefits required by Kentucky state law, the file should be forwarded to legal counsel to avoid further delays. She concluded by noting that Shannon’s claim had already experienced a significant delay, which she found unacceptable.

Kaitlin Ericksen replied later on February 20, 2025, at 3:54 PM, informing Tuttle that UPS had confirmed suitable light-duty work was available, and as a result, Liberty Mutual would not be issuing TTD benefits at that time.

Shortly after, at approximately 5:55 PM, Tuttle pushed back in a follow-up email. She reiterated that Shannon had missed days due to the injury and that UPS could not provide suitable light-duty work. She urged that TTD payments be backdated to the incident date to cover days Shannon could not work. She stated that Flaget Memorial had placed Shannon off work for at least three days (February 11–14, 2025) and that Shannon had been placed off work indefinitely as of that afternoon, attaching the same Work Statement from Advanced Injury Rehab. She emphasized the need to initiate TTD benefits and warned of ongoing delays if the benefits were not issued. She expressly noted that Shannon’s claim had been intentionally delayed for nearly two weeks and regarded this as unacceptable.

In a broader thread dated February 25, 2025, at 11:41 AM, Sarena Tuttle again addressed Kaitlin Ericksen and attached additional certified medical records from Concentra and Flaget Memorial Hospital. She restated that Liberty Mutual had not yet responded to their February 20 correspondence concerning TTD benefits and Form 114 reimbursements. She also revisited the Concentra records, reiterating that the wrong job description had apparently been provided to Concentra, who listed “Air Handler” as the job title and used the Air Handler restrictions. Tuttle asked Liberty Mutual to confirm that the correct job title in the file is indeed “Full Time Fueler,” emphasizing that these two job descriptions involve vastly different duties. She explained that Shannon’s immediate supervisor could not accommodate the restrictions, noting that Shannon had been placed off work on February 20 for an indefinite period and indicating that Shannon would be updating medical documentation with an unbiased provider later that afternoon. She pressed for an immediate update on the status of the claim and for the initiation of benefits if appropriate.

That same day, February 25, 2025, at 6:38 PM, Kaitlin Ericksen responded with a summary of Liberty Mutual’s position. She stated that UPS had advised there was work available within Shannon’s restrictions and, because modified work was available, TTD benefits could not be issued through February 19, 2025. Liberty Mutual planned to issue Shannon’s first TTD check on February 28, 2025, with February 20, 2025 identified as the first day of TTD issued. Ericksen also indicated that a mileage reimbursement check would be requested.

Throughout the exchanges, the parties repeatedly referenced the confidentiality and privilege notices typical of such communications, and the correspondence included the standard privacy policy notice. They also included the broader context of Shannon Lankswert’s injuries, including a Tailbone Injury noted in Flaget records, and references to medical treatment strategies and accommodations being pursued by Shannon through an independent provider.

In summary, the key points across the correspondence are as follows: Shannon Lankswert’s claim WC80D-H07503 faced a dispute over TTD benefits due to reports of available modified work; there was a significant discrepancy between the job title on Concentra’s records (“Air Handler”) and the actual job title Shannon held (“Full Time Fueler”); Shannon had been off work since February 20 for an indefinite period, with a short initial off-work period (February 11–14) confirmed by Flaget Memorial; Liberty Mutual ultimately indicated that TTD benefits would not be paid for periods in which modified work was available, and that the first TTD check would be issued on February 28, 2025, with February 20, 2025 as the first day of TTD, while a mileage reimbursement check would also be requested. Shannon’s counsel, through The Whaley Law Firm, continued to seek prompt initiation of TTD benefits and to clarify the correct job description in the file, citing Kentucky state law and the need to avoid further delays.

episodes.natural_language:
This narrative summarizes the communications in the Shannon Lankswert workers’ compensation case (Case: Shannon-Lankswert-WC-02-07-2025; WC80D-H07503), as documented in the exchanged emails between The Whaley Law Firm and Liberty Mutual, and the positions taken by UPS where relevant. The Whaley Law Firm is represented by Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, and the recipient from Liberty Mutual is Kaitlin Ericksen, a Claims Specialist II. The file includes references to the Certified Medical Records from Concentra and Flaget Memorial Hospital, as well as a Work Statement from Advanced Injury Rehab, and discusses TTD benefits, accommodations, and potential reimbursement of expenses (Form 114). Sarena’s signature in the messages notes a new email address: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with the firm’s Louisville, Kentucky contact information.

The matter centers on whether accommodations were available for Shannon Lankswert after her work injury and whether temporary total disability (TTD) benefits should be paid. In late February 2025, questions arose about who was stating that accommodations were available, since Mrs. Lankswert’s immediate supervisor had told her there were none. The firm asserted that even if there had been incorrect guidance given to Ms. Lankswert, it was not her fault and that the situation needed to be addressed and rectified promptly; otherwise, the file should be sent to Liberty Mutual’s legal department for proper resolution.

On February 20, 2025, Kaitlin Ericksen advised that UPS had indicated work within Mrs. Lankswert’s restrictions was available, and that modified work was ongoing. Consequently, Liberty Mutual stated they could not issue TTD benefits through February 19, 2025. They planned to issue Ms. Lankswert’s first TTD check on February 28, 2025, with February 20, 2025 as the first day of TTD, and they would also request a mileage reimbursement check.

Earlier in the day, on February 20, 2025, Sarena Tuttle had warned that Ms. Lankswert had missed days due to the injury and that UPS could not provide suitable light-duty work. She argued that TTD payments should be backdated to the date of the incident to cover the days Ms. Lankswert could not work. Flaget Memorial had placed Ms. Lankswert off work for at least three days (February 11–14, 2025), and she had been placed off work indefinitely as of that afternoon, pending her next evaluation. She attached a Work Statement from Advanced Injury Rehab and urged the initiation of TTD benefits, which she said had been requested multiple times. She cautioned that continued delays could lead to escalation to Liberty Mutual’s legal counsel to avoid further delays, describing the claim as intentionally delayed for nearly two weeks.

In response, on February 20, 2025 at 3:54 PM, Kaitlin Ericksen reiterated that UPS had confirmed suitable light-duty work was available and, accordingly, Liberty Mutual would not issue TTD benefits at that time.

Earlier still, at 1:44 PM on February 20, 2025, Sarena Tuttle had written that Ms. Lankswert should be compensated from the date of the incident until she was released back to full duty. She described Ms. Lankswert as a Fuel Truck Driver who must sit for long periods, lift heavy hoses, and climb stairs—activities that contribute to pain and delay recovery. She asserted that Concentra had placed restrictions on Ms. Lankswert and suggested that UPS had given a standing order—allegedly driven by non-medical personnel—to avoid placing UPS employees off work. She explained that she could not drive due to an inability to sit for long periods and could not lift hoses; she emphasized that the restrictions from Concentra did not permit her to fulfill duties as a Full Time Fueler. The note in the chronology ends mid-sentence, indicating the message was cut off.

On February 25, 2025 at 11:41 AM, Sarena sent the email that included attachments of the Certified Medical Records from Concentra and Flaget Memorial Hospital related to Mrs. Lankswert’s injuries. She noted that there had been no response to Liberty Mutual correspondence dated February 20, 2025 regarding TTD benefits and Form 114 reimbursements. After reviewing the Concentra records, she observed that the wrong job description had been provided to Concentra: they had been given “Air Handler” as Mrs. Lankswert’s job title and had based restrictions on the Air Handler description. She asked Kaitlin to confirm that Liberty Mutual’s file reflected the correct job title, “Full Time Fueler,” explaining that this is a substantially different role from an Air Handler who sorts packages for a short period (3–4 hours per shift). She noted that the two departments are distinct and reiterated that Mrs. Lankswert’s immediate supervisor could not accommodate the provided restrictions, but that she had been placed off work on February 20, 2025 for an indefinite period, presumably pending the next evaluation. She requested an immediate update on the status of the claim.

Following this, at 1:38 PM on February 25, 2025, Kaitlin Ericksen replied that UPS had advised work within the restrictions was available and that, since modified work was available, Liberty Mutual would not issue TTD benefits through February 19, 2025. She stated that the first TTD check would be issued on February 28, 2025, with February 20, 2025 as the first day of TTD, and she would also request that a mileage reimbursement check be issued.

In addition to these exchanges, prior messages in the chain emphasize the ongoing tension between the need to compensate for time off work due to the injury (TTD and Form 114 reimbursements) and the determination that suitable light-duty work could be performed within the restrictions provided by Concentra and UPS’s practices. The correspondence also references the attached medical records and the discrepancy between the job descriptions used by Concentra and the actual role held by Ms. Lankswert, underscoring the need to confirm the correct job title in the file and to address the resulting discrepancies in accommodations and benefits.

This narrative reflects all facts and details contained in the structured case note: the dates of the communications (February 20 and 25, 2025), the involved parties and their roles, the references to TTD benefits and Form 114 reimbursements, the discrepancy between job titles (“Air Handler” vs. “Full Time Fueler”), the UPS standing-order assertions, the off-work status starting February 20, 2025, the attachments (Certified Medical Records, Work Statement, and a request for immediate updates), and the specific actions requested by both sides (rectifying accommodations, backdating TTD where appropriate, and issuing checks).

__Re: Shannon Lankswert v UPS__
From: Sarena Tuttle [sarena@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:sarena@whaleylawfirm.com)
To: Taylor Wood [twood@lucasdietzlaw.com](mailto:twood@lucasdietzlaw.com), LLucas@lucasdietzlaw.com 
CC: Bryce Koon [bryce@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:bryce@whaleylawfirm.com)
Date: Thu, 27 Feb 2025 16:06:20 -0500

Thank you so much Taylor.
Good afternoon Mr. Lucas,
 Thank you so much for reaching out to us. Mr. Bryce Koon is the
attorney of record for our firm, I have included his contact information
below. Just to update you on the claim to date, Ms. Lankswert is a
Full-time (8hr) Fueler for United Parcel Service, who on Friday,
February 7, 2025 fell down a set of metal stairs (photo provided) while
within the scope of her employment. Ms. Lankswert immediately felt pain in
both elbows & her lower back from the impact on the stairs. Shortly after,
she was transported by another UPS Employee in their personal vehicle to
Concentra Health on Fern Valley Road. Concentra advised Ms. Lankswert that
they '...are not allowed to place UPS employees off work by law, due to
their account with UPS' and sent Ms. Lankswert back to full duty while
documenting a limited ROM in her arms. Ms. Lankswert was off work over the
weekend and attempted to recover at home.
 On February 11, 2025 Ms. Lankswert was still in immense pain and could
not await her follow up appointment with Concentra. Ms. Lankswert was seen
at Flaget Memorial Hospital who advised Ms. Lankswert to avoid driving,
sitting, or standing for long periods of time as well as to rest. Ms.
Lankswert then returned to Concentra on February 13, 2025, where she
explained to the physician that she was not able to fulfill her duties due
to the pain & Concentra provided restrictions for Ms. Lankswert. UPS
provided Concentra with a job description for an 'Air Handler', not a
'Fueler' and Concentra based their restrictions on the incorrect position
and stated Ms. Lankswert was about to return to modified duty & work her
full shift. When Ms. Lankswert shared these restrictions with her immediate
supervisor, Amy Roy, Ms. Roy advised Ms. Lankswert that they were not able
to accommodate her restrictions. Unfortunately, she was not scheduled to
see Concentra again for another 4 days, on February 17, 2025.
 From the date of her injury through February 17th, 2025, UPS made no
mention nor took any actions to discuss workers' compensation with Ms.
Lankswert. Instead, each evening (3rd shift employee), Ms. Roy would
contact Ms. Lankswert & ask her how she, Ms. Lankswert, wanted her off time
to 'coded' and given only the options of 'Call In', 'PTO' or 'Vacation'. On
at least one occasion, Ms. Lankswert was advised the 'Board was full' and
she had to take a Call In Occurrence. On February 14th, Ms. Lankswert
attempted to go in to work for her 'light duty position' and advised to sit
in the breakroom for the evening as they had no work available for her. Ms.
Lankswert was unable to stay her whole shift as the plastic chairs & steel
stools (photo provided) were causing more pain to her tailbone injury.
 Ms. Lankswert attended her February 17th appointment with Concentra
and felt her injuries were not being properly addressed so she followed up
the next day (02.18) with Advanced Injury & Rehab who placed Ms. Lankswert
off work until her MRI imaging results were obtained. The MRI shows at
least 2 bulging discs in Ms. Lankswert's lower lumbar spine and she has
been ordered to physical therapy.
 To date, Ms. Lankswert still has not received any information from UPS
in regards to her workers compensation claim. Our contact with the WC
Carrier has been very limited and only consists of continued denial of Ms.
Lankswert's TTD benefits from the Date of her incident through February
20th. The Adjuster is very short and only states UPS says there is
'suitable light duty' available to Ms. Lankswert, which is in direct
contradiction of Ms. Lankswert's immediate supervisor. When asked who is
stating there is suitable work, there is no response, only denial of
benefits.
 At this time, Ms. Lankswert has only work approximately 2 hrs (sitting
in a breakroom) since the date of her incident. We have requested that TTD
Benefits be issued & that her attendance status be reinstated as she should
not have accrued any Call Ins, used PTO and/or Vacation time in relation to
her work related injury. The Adjuster just simply states there is suitable
work able & denies benefits. We look forward to working with you toward an
amicable resolution and hearing from you shortly.

W. Bryce Koon
(502) 583-4022 Ext 114
Bryce@WhaleyLawFirm.com

This note covers the Shannon-Lankswert-WC-02-07-2025 case, involving client Shannon Lankswert and the claim against United Parcel Service (UPS). On February 7, 2025, Shannon Lankswert, who works full-time (8 hours) as a Fueler for UPS, fell down a set of metal stairs in the course of her employment (photos of the incident are provided in the attached materials). She immediately experienced pain in both elbows and her lower back from the impact. She was transported by another UPS employee in the employee’s personal vehicle to Concentra Health on Fern Valley Road. Concentra advised that they “are not allowed to place UPS employees off work by law, due to their account with UPS,” and they sent Ms. Lankswert back to full duty while documenting a limited range of motion in her arms. She was off work over the weekend and attempted to recover at home.

By February 11, 2025, Ms. Lankswert was still in immense pain and could not wait for her follow-up appointment with Concentra. She was seen at Flaget Memorial Hospital, which advised her to avoid driving, sitting, or standing for long periods and to rest. She then returned to Concentra on February 13, 2025, where she explained that she could not fulfill her duties due to the pain, and Concentra provided restrictions for her. UPS had supplied Concentra with a job description for an “Air Handler,” not a “Fueler,” and Concentra based their restrictions on the incorrect position, stating that Ms. Lankswert was about to return to modified duty and work her full shift. When Ms. Lankswert shared these restrictions with her immediate supervisor, Amy Roy, Ms. Roy advised that they were not able to accommodate her restrictions. She was not scheduled to see Concentra again for another four days, until February 17, 2025.

From the date of her injury through February 17, 2025, UPS did not mention or take any action to discuss workers’ compensation with Ms. Lankswert. Instead, each evening (3rd shift), Ms. Roy would contact Ms. Lankswert and ask how she wanted her off time to be coded, offering the options “Call In,” “PTO,” or “Vacation.” On at least one occasion, Ms. Lankswert was told the “Board was full” and that she had to take a Call In Occurrence. On February 14, Ms. Lankswert attempted to go to work for a “light duty position” but was told to sit in the breakroom for the evening because there was no work available for her. She could not stay the entire shift because the plastic chairs and steel stools (photos provided) aggravated her tailbone injury.

Ms. Lankswert attended her February 17 appointment with Concentra and felt that her injuries were not being properly addressed, so she followed up on February 18 with Advanced Injury & Rehab, which placed her off work until MRI results were obtained. The MRI revealed at least two bulging discs in her lower lumbar spine, and she has been ordered to physical therapy.

To date, Ms. Lankswert has not received any information from UPS regarding her workers’ compensation claim. Our contact with the workers’ compensation carrier has been very limited and has consisted solely of continued denial of Ms. Lankswert’s temporary total disability (TTD) benefits from the date of her incident through February 20. The adjuster states that UPS says there is “suitable light duty” available, which contradicts what her immediate supervisor has communicated. When asked who is stating there is suitable work, there is no response, only a denial of benefits.

As of now, Ms. Lankswert has only worked approximately two hours (sitting in a breakroom) since the date of her incident. We have requested that TTD benefits be issued and that her attendance status be reinstated, as she should not have accrued any Call In, PTO, or Vacation time in relation to this work-related injury. The adjuster simply states there is suitable work available and denies benefits. We look forward to working toward an amicable resolution and hearing from you soon.

- Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; D: (502) 357-9971; O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104; E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS)

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Shannon-Lankswert-WC-02-07-2025 documents the ongoing representation matter for Shannon Lankswert in her workers’ compensation claim against United Parcel Service (UPS). On March 10, 2025, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to counsel for UPS (Taylor Wood and LLucas) with Ms. Lankswert’s updated Work Status Note attached. The note states that Ms. Lankswert will remain off work until her next evaluation on March 13, 2025. Tuttle requested acknowledgment of receipt and an updated status of Ms. Lankswert’s claim. She also noted that, to date, there had been no response to their acknowledgment of representation or the requested documents in their letter of representation sent to Liberty Mutual on February 20, 2025. Tuttle provided her contact information and reminded recipients of her new Whaley Law Firm email address.

The March 10 email followed an earlier chain beginning February 27, 2025. In a message dated February 27, 2025, at approximately 4:06 PM, Sarena Tuttle indicated that Bryce Koon is the attorney of record for The Whaley Law Firm and provided his contact information. She updated the claim as follows: Ms. Lankswert is a full-time employee working eight hours as a Fueler for UPS. On Friday, February 7, 2025, she fell down a set of metal stairs within the scope of her employment, and immediately felt pain in both elbows and her lower back from the impact. She was transported by another UPS employee in a personal vehicle to Concentra Health on Fern Valley Road. Concentra told her they “are not allowed to place UPS employees off work by law, due to their account with UPS,” and they sent her back to full duty while documenting a limited range of motion in her arms. She remained off work over the weekend and attempted to recover at home.

On February 11, 2025, Ms. Lankswert remained in significant pain and could not await her follow-up appointment with Concentra. She was seen at Flaget Memorial Hospital, which advised her to avoid driving, sitting, or standing for long periods and to rest. She then returned to Concentra on February 13, 2025, where she explained that she could not fulfill her duties due to pain, and Concentra issued restrictions for her. UPS provided Concentra with a job description for an “Air Handler,” not a “Fueler,” and Concentra based their restrictions on this incorrect position, stating that Ms. Lankswert was about to return to modified duty and work her full shift. When Ms. Lankswert shared these restrictions with her immediate supervisor, Amy Roy, Roy advised that they could not accommodate the restrictions. She was not scheduled to see Concentra again for another four days, on February 17, 2025.

From the date of her injury through February 17, 2025, UPS made no mention or actions to discuss workers’ compensation with Ms. Lankswert. Instead, each evening (the third shift), Amy Roy would contact Ms. Lankswert and ask how she wanted her off time coded, offering only the options of “Call In,” “PTO,” or “Vacation.” On at least one occasion, Ms. Lankswert was told the “Board was full” and she had to take a Call In Occurrence. On February 14th, Ms. Lankswert attempted to go to work for a “light duty position” and was instructed to sit in the breakroom for the evening because there was no work available for her. She could not stay the entire shift because the plastic chairs and steel stools in the breakroom caused more pain to her tailbone injury.

Ms. Lankswert attended her February 17th appointment with Concentra and felt that her injuries were not being properly addressed, so she followed up on February 18, 2025, with Advanced Injury & Rehab, which placed her off work until MRI results were obtained. The MRI showed at least two bulging discs in her lower lumbar spine, and she has been ordered to physical therapy. To date, Ms. Lankswert has received no information from UPS regarding her workers’ compensation claim. Communication with the workers’ compensation carrier has been very limited and has consisted only of continued denial of her temporary total disability (TTD) benefits from the date of her incident through February 20, 2025. The adjuster conveyed, in a curt manner, that UPS says there is “suitable light duty” available for Ms. Lankswert, which contradicts the position of her immediate supervisor. When asked who was stating there is suitable work, there was no response beyond denial of benefits. As of the report, Ms. Lankswert has only worked approximately two hours (sitting in a breakroom) since the date of her incident. The firm has requested that TTD benefits be issued and that her attendance status be reinstated, noting that she should not have accrued any Call In, PTO, or Vacation time related to her work-related injury. The adjuster’s position remains that there is suitable work available and that benefits should be denied. The Whaley Law Firm indicates a desire to work toward an amicable resolution and anticipates a prompt response from the opposing counsel.

In addition to the narrative of the claim, the February 27, 2025 email includes the signatories and contact details for the parties: W. Bryce Koon, reachable at (502) 583-4022, Ext. 114, Bryce@WhaleyLawFirm.com; and Sarena M. Tuttle, reachable at (502) 357-9971 (D) and (502) 583-4022, Ext. 104, Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with the notice to use the new email address. The email also lists three attachments: 2025.02.17 Lankswert CPD Doctor Notes.pdf; 2025.02.17 Lankswert CPD Injury Photos - Both Arms & Tail Bone Bruising.pdf; and 2025.02.17 Lankswert CPD Text w Supervisor - Screenshots.pdf.

Also on February 27, 2025, Taylor Wood of Lucas & Dietz, PLLC sent a separate email confirming that a letter of representation had been attached regarding the above-referenced claim. Wood noted that Lance Lucas would handle the claim unless hard copies were requested to be mailed. The message, which included Taylor Wood’s contact information and a standard confidentiality disclaimer, closed with guidance that hard copies would not be mailed unless requested.

In summary, the records depict a significant early injury on February 7, 2025, with subsequent missteps in medical–legal handling, incorrect job descriptions used to justify restrictions, a lack of timely benefit payments or case discussions from the carrier, ongoing denial of TTD benefits, and an extended period of limited or no meaningful work for Ms. Lankswert, all accompanied by repeated requests for acknowledgment, representation, and documentation from the defense team and their client. The notes also show ongoing communications through March 2025, including updated work status and documentation intended to support ongoing disability and compensation claims.

They noted that UPS had delayed processing this claim and that Shannon’s immediate supervisor had advised that they could not accommodate the restrictions set by Concentra. Despite these restrictions, Shannon was still required to drive more than 35 miles to the property and to sit in a breakroom for the evening. Because of her injuries, she had been advised not to drive for long periods and she could not sit in the chairs provided (photos were included). As a result, Shannon was forced to use vacation time and received occurrences for the missed time. The firm urged that TTD (Temporary Total Disability) benefits begin processing as soon as possible and asked that Shannon’s vacation time and Attendance Status be reinstated promptly to avoid future issues. They emphasized that Shannon Lankswert should not have accrued any occurrences or been punished for her work-related injury. The message closed with an invitation for questions and a commitment to work toward an amicable resolution. The attachments referenced were the representation letter and the KY DWC forms (106, 113, 114) along with the injury and scene photos.

That same February 20, 2025 thread also included a forwarding of the prior communications. The forwarded message from The Whaley Law Firm’s Sarena Tuttle to Kaitlin Ericksen (Cc: Bryce Koon) reiterated the contents described above: the office’s letter of representation, the KY DWC Form 106, 113, and 114, and the related photos, plus the note about Shannon’s 2:00 PM appointment and the ongoing issues with processing by UPS, the restrictions by Concentra, and Shannon’s travel and seating hardships. The message again stressed the need to begin processing Shannon’s TTD benefits and to reinstate her vacation time and Attendance Status to prevent future problems, asserting that Shannon should not have incurred any negative occurrences due to her work-related injury.

Also on February 20, 2025, the original message from Kaitlin Ericksen (sent at about 10:36 AM) stated: Good morning, I am the adjuster who has been assigned to Shannon Lankswert’s workers compensation claim. Please let me know if you need anything. This established the initial point of contact for the claim.

The case file also includes the standard confidentiality notice typical of Liberty Mutual emails, indicating that the information contained in the email and any attachments is confidential and may be privileged or constitute attorney work product. It instructs unintended recipients to notify the sender, refrain from using or distributing the information, and destroy all copies; it also notes that a privacy notice is available on Liberty Mutual’s privacy policy website. The Whaley Law Firm’s communications also include contact details and note a new email address for Sarena M. Tuttle: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, along with the firm’s Louisville office address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and phone numbers: D (502) 357-9971 and O (502) 583-4022 ext 104.

In addition to these February 2025 exchanges, on March 7, 2025, Shannon Lankswert’s contact, Shannon Mattingly (smm75mj@msn.com), replied to the Whaley Law Firm regarding WC80D-H07503 Shannon Lankswert. The message, with the subject Re: WC80D-H07503 Shannon Lankswert, was sent from Shannon Mattingly to Sarena Tuttle at 21:45:59 UTC, indicating ongoing communications between Shannon and the firm regarding the case. The original email lines show the correspondence was prepared for review on iOS, as indicated by the standard Outlook for iOS signature, and the firm’s representative details were included in the message thread.

This series of exchanges documents the assignment of a new adjuster, the office’s representation, the forms filed (KY DWC Forms 106, 113, 114), patient appointment scheduling, transport and seating constraints tied to Shannon’s injuries, the impact on her work time (vacation use and occurrences), the request to commence TTD benefits, and the firm’s guidance to coordinate with the office rather than direct contact with the adjuster. It also records the client’s and the firm’s ongoing efforts to secure an amicable resolution and to ensure Shannon is not unfairly penalized for injury-related absence, while preserving all relevant dates, forms, photos, and contact information from the communications.
