episodes.natural_language:
Case: Shannon-Lankswert-WC-02-07-2025
Client: Shannon Lankswert

In the matter of Shannon Lankswert v UPS, the Whaley Law Firm represented Shannon Lankswert. The Whaley Law Firm initially reached out to Lucas & Dietz, PLLC, in mid-February 2025 to formalize representation and to forward requested documents to the defense and the workers’ compensation carrier. On February 27, 2025, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager for The Whaley Law Firm, sent a detailed communication describing Shannon Lankswert’s claim history and the status of communications with UPS and the carrier, and attached material related to the claim. The February 27 communication also noted that Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm is the attorney of record and included contact information for both Mr. Koon and Ms. Tuttle.

On March 14, 2025, Sarena M. Tuttle again wrote to Taylor Wood and Mr. Lucas, with Bryce Koon copied, to express concern that more than two weeks had passed since the representation letter had been received and acknowledged, and to note that no documents had yet been received despite the request having been made more than six weeks prior. The email asked to confirm that Lucas & Dietz continues to serve as Shannon Lankswert’s legal counsel and to immediately forward the documents that had been requested. The message emphasized an interest in an amicable resolution but stated that the ongoing delays were discouraging and urged contact to discuss the claim promptly. The message was signed by Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s Louisville, Kentucky address and direct lines, and noting a new email address for contact.

Earlier, on March 10, 2025, at approximately 10:16 AM (the timestamp appears as 10:16? AM in the chain), Ms. Tuttle sent another note stating that Shannon Lankswert’s work status update had been attached, indicating that Ms. Lankswert would remain off work until her next evaluation on March 13, 2025. The message asked the recipients to acknowledge receipt and provide an updated status of Ms. Lankswert’s claim. It also highlighted that to date the firm had not received any response to their acknowledgement of representation nor any of the requested documents in their February 20, 2025 letter to Liberty Mutual.

The February 27, 2025 communications from The Whaley Law Firm provided a detailed narrative of the claim. In that correspondence, it was stated that Shannon Lankswert is a full-time (8-hour) Fueler for United Parcel Service. On Friday, February 7, 2025, she fell down a set of metal stairs within the scope of her employment, and immediately experienced pain in both elbows and her lower back from the impact. She was transported by another UPS employee in that employee’s personal vehicle to Concentra Health on Fern Valley Road. Concentra advised that they are not allowed to place UPS employees off work by law due to their account with UPS, and they sent Ms. Lankswert back to full duty while documenting a limited range of motion (ROM) in her arms. She remained off work over the weekend and attempted to recover at home.

On February 11, 2025, Ms. Lankswert was still in substantial pain and could not wait for her follow-up appointment with Concentra. She was seen at Flaget Memorial Hospital, where she was advised to avoid driving, sitting, or standing for long periods and to rest. She returned to Concentra on February 13, 2025, where she explained that she could not fulfill her duties due to the pain, and Concentra provided restrictions for Ms. Lankswert. UPS had provided Concentra with a job description for an “Air Handler,” not a “Fueler,” and Concentra based their restrictions on the incorrect position, stating that Ms. Lankswert was about to return to modified duty and work her full shift. When Ms. Lankswert shared these restrictions with her immediate supervisor, Amy Roy, Ms. Roy advised that they could not accommodate the restrictions. She was not scheduled to see Concentra again for another four days, on February 17, 2025.

From the date of her injury through February 17, 2025, UPS did not mention or take any action to discuss workers’ compensation with Ms. Lankswert. Instead, each evening, Ms. Roy, a third-shift employee, would contact Ms. Lankswert and ask how she wanted her off time coded, offering only the options of “Call In,” “PTO,” or “Vacation.” On February 14, 2025, Ms. Lankswert attempted to go to work for a light-duty position and was told to sit in the breakroom for the evening since there was no work available. She was unable to stay for her entire shift because the plastic chairs and steel stools caused additional pain to her tailbone injury, as evidenced by accompanying photos.

Ms. Lankswert attended her February 17, 2025, appointment with Concentra and felt that her injuries were not being properly addressed, leading her to follow up on February 18, 2025, with Advanced Injury & Rehab, which placed her off work until MRI results were obtained. The MRI revealed at least two bulging discs in her lower lumbar spine, and she was ordered to physical therapy. To date, Shannon Lankswert has not received any information from UPS regarding her workers’ compensation claim. The Whaley Law Firm reported that contact with the workers’ compensation carrier had been very limited and that the only communication was a continued denial of temporary total disability (TTD) benefits from the date of the incident through February 20, 2025. The adjuster reportedly stated that there is “suitable light duty” available for Ms. Lankswert, which contradicted her immediate supervisor. When asked who indicated there was suitable work, there was no response other than continued denial of benefits. By that time, Ms. Lankswert had only worked approximately two hours since the date of her incident, consisting of time spent sitting in a breakroom. The firm requested that TTD benefits be issued and her attendance status reinstated, noting that she should not have accrued any “Call Ins,” PTO, or Vacation time related to her work-related injury. The adjuster’s stance remained that there was suitable work available and that benefits should be denied. The Whaley Law Firm expressed their intent to work toward an amicable resolution and looked forward to hearing from the defense promptly.

Accompanying the February 27, 2025 correspondence were several documents: 2025.02.17 Lankswert CPD Doctor Notes.pdf; 2025.02.17 Lankswert CPD Injury Photos - Both Arms & Tail Bone Bruising.pdf; and 2025.02.17 Lankswert CPD Text w Supervisor - Screenshots.pdf.

Additionally, on February 27, 2025 at approximately 2:43 PM, Taylor Wood of LUCAS & DIETZ, PLLC replied with a message Good afternoon, noting that a letter of representation had been attached regarding the above-referenced claim and that Lance Lucas would be handling the claim unless hard copies were requested to be mailed. The message included professional courtesy and contact details for Taylor Wood, Paralegal at LUCAS & DIETZ, PLLC, including the Florence, Kentucky office address and phone numbers.

Shortly after, at approximately 4:06 PM on February 27, 2025, Sarena Tuttle sent the detailed representation letter (the extensive narrative above), reiterating Shannon Lankswert’s status, the medical timeline, and the ongoing issues with the claim, UPS response (or lack thereof), and the workers’ compensation process. The email also listed the Whaley Law Firm’s and Ms. Tuttle’s contact information and included a note about the attachments.

This email chain further included a note indicating that the body of the message was intended to be confidential and protected by attorney-client or other applicable privileges, and that the information was non-public and trade secrets, intended only for the recipient(s).

In summary, the record contains a sequence of communications beginning with the February 27, 2025 representation and claim history disclosure from The Whaley Law Firm, followed by a February 27, 2025 response from LUCAS & DIETZ confirming representation and assigning Lance Lucas, then updated communications in March 2025 documenting Shannon Lankswert’s continued off-work status, her medical findings (including MRI showing at least two bulging discs in the lower lumbar spine and a prescription for physical therapy), limited or denied benefits from the workers’ compensation carrier, ongoing questions about the availability of suitable light duty versus the supervisor’s guidance, and the firm’s pursuit of an amicable resolution along with delivery of supporting documents and medical files. The communications emphasize the lack of timely responses to the representation letters (noted as sent February 20, 2025 to Liberty Mutual) and the ongoing difficulties Shannon Lankswert faced in obtaining information and benefits related to her claim.

Client: Shannon Lankswert

__Re: WC80D-H07503 Shannon Lankswert__
From: Sarena Tuttle [sarena@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:sarena@whaleylawfirm.com)
To: "Ericksen , Kaitlin" [Kaitlin.Ericksen@libertymutual.com](mailto:Kaitlin.Ericksen@libertymutual.com), Lance Lucas [LLucas@lucasdietzlaw.com](mailto:LLucas@lucasdietzlaw.com), Taylor Wood [twood@lucasdietzlaw.com](mailto:twood@lucasdietzlaw.com)
CC: Bryce Koon [bryce@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:bryce@whaleylawfirm.com)
Date: Tue, 18 Mar 2025 14:30:48 -0400

Good afternoon everyone,
 We have spoken with Ms. Lankswert's provider moments ago & they are
continuing to keep Ms. Lankswert Off Work until March 27, 2025 at which
time she will be re-evaluated. Please continue her TTD benefits and provide
an update on the past due TTD Benefits from the start of the claims
process.
 Further, we have received and reviewed the First Report Of Injury
(FROI) from yesterday's discussion and see there are several discrepancies
noted in the report. Beginning with her Pay Information, it is noted that
she is paid $999.99 a week, 3 days a week, and her salary did continue.
Mrs. Lankswert is a full time employee who works 5 days a week and her
salary did not continue, she was forced to use PTO & Vacation Time. 2nd,
her injuries are listed as a contusion on her elbow. There is no mention of
her back injury and the bulging disc that resulted from her fall. 3rd, the
Description of the incident, the report indicates she slipped on the 3rd of
4 steps, however, our understanding is that she slipped on the top step &
hit 3 steps on her way down. We are aware there are cameras covering this
specific area & have requested the surveillance footage from that time of
the incident with no response or acknowledgement from the Adjuster and or
your office. 4th, the report indicates "No Lost Time", as discussed Ms.
Lankswert has not returned to work due to her injuries and has now missed
26 work days with the exception of 2 hours she was forced to sit in the
breakroom until she could be properly evaluated by an unbiased medical
provider. Lastly, the report indicates "No Medical Treatment" under Initial
Treatment. Ms. Lankswert was immediately transported by her management team
to Concentra the same night of the incident.
 All of these items definitely make this incident seem very minor in
contrast to the reality of the situation and severity of Ms. Lankswert's
injuries. We have attached KAR 803.025.240 for your review & reference,
specifically highlighting Section 3, 4, 5, 6 & 7, all of which seem to be
in question in relation to this claim and the unfair claims practices that
are clearly evident in this file. At this time, we again request the
following as outlined in our initial letter of representation dated
February 20th, 2025:

Pursuant to Civil Rule 26 and 803 KAR 25:010(8), *please furnish an updated
and complete copy of the injured worker’s claim file within fifteen days of
this notice. This is a continuing request, which includes but is not
limited to*:

[1] Medical records;

[2] Pre-employment physicals/screenings/urinalysis;

[3] Average weekly wage documentation, including one year of wage records
preceding the injury;

[4] Temporary Total Disability ledger;

[5] Job description;

[6] Incident/OSHA reports[s], First Report of Injury and;

[7] Any photographs, video footage or recorded statements.

[8] Any and all Lien Information for At Fault 3rd Party

Sarena M. Tuttle
Litigation Paralegal &
Workers' Compensation Case Manager
The Whaley Law Firm
712 Lyndon Lane
Louisville, KY 40222
D: (502) 357-9971
O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Shannon-Lankswert-WC-02-07-2025. Client: Shannon Lankswert. This note concerns the file WC80D-H07503 for Shannon Lankswert and documents communications dated March 18, 2025, among The Whaley Law Firm and Liberty Mutual claims personnel, with Lance Lucas and Taylor Wood also copied, and Bryce Koon CC’d. The message was sent by Sarena Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm.

In a March 18, 2025 communication, The Whaley Law Firm advised that they had spoken with Ms. Lankswert’s provider moments earlier and that the provider continues to keep Ms. Lankswert off work through March 27, 2025, at which time she will be re-evaluated. The firm asked Liberty Mutual to continue Ms. Lankswert’s temporary total disability (TTD) benefits and to provide an update on the past-due TTD benefits from the start of the claim. They additionally stated that they had received and reviewed the First Report Of Injury (FROI) discussed the previous day and identified several discrepancies within the report.

Regarding pay information in the FROI, the report reportedly shows Ms. Lankswert is paid $999.99 per week for three days of work, and that her salary continued. The firm clarified that Ms. Lankswert is a full-time employee who works five days per week, and that her salary did not continue; she was instead required to use paid time off (PTO) and vacation time. The second discrepancy concerns the injuries listed: the FROI lists a contusion on her elbow, with no mention of a back injury or the bulging disc that resulted from her fall. The third discrepancy concerns the incident description: the report states she slipped on the third of four steps, whereas the firm’s understanding is that she slipped on the top step and struck three steps on her way down. The firm noted cameras cover the area and stated they had requested the surveillance footage from the time of the incident, but had not received a response or acknowledgment from the adjuster or Liberty Mutual. The fourth issue concerns “No Lost Time” in the FROI; in contrast, the firm stated that Ms. Lankswert has not returned to work due to injuries and has missed 26 workdays, with the exception of two hours she was required to sit in the breakroom until she could be properly evaluated by an unbiased medical provider. The final discrepancy noted is that the FROI indicates “No Medical Treatment” under Initial Treatment, while Ms. Lankswert was immediately transported by her management team to Concentra on the night of the incident.

The Whaley Law Firm asserted that these items strongly imply the incident is far more serious than a minor event would suggest. They attached KAR 803.025.240 for review, specifically highlighting Sections 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7, which they stated appear to be in question regarding the claim and the unfair claims practices they alleged are evident in the file. They reiterated their demand, consistent with their initial letter of representation dated February 20, 2025, for an updated and complete copy of the injured worker’s claim file within fifteen days of the notice, pursuant to Civil Rule 26 and 803 KAR 25:010(8). The request was to include, but not be limited to, the following items: (1) medical records; (2) pre-employment physicals, screenings, and urinalysis; (3) average weekly wage documentation, including one year of wage records preceding the injury; (4) temporary total disability ledger; (5) job description; (6) incident/OSHA reports and the First Report of Injury; (7) any photographs, video footage, or recorded statements; and (8) any and all lien information for at-fault third parties.

The message was signed by Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, with contact details: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line 502-357-9971; office line 502-583-4022 ext. 104; and email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, noting a new email address. The note also bore the standard request to acknowledge receipt and the confidentiality notice.

In a subsequent exchange on March 18, 2025, around 11:09 a.m. (time noted as tentative), Sarena Tuttle informed Kaitlin that, with legal counsel involved, all correspondence should be routed through the law office, and that they had forwarded the last off-work statement they had received to Mr. Lucas. They stated they had reached out to Ms. Lankswert and her provider for an update since her appointment at the end of the previous week and were awaiting a response.

Kaitlin Ericksen of Liberty Mutual replied around 9:30 a.m. on the same day, stating that she had been unable to release Ms. Lankswert’s most recent TTD check because Liberty Mutual had not yet received an updated work note or medical records from the appointment on March 7, 2025, and requested a copy of the work note from that appointment.

The overall narrative reflects that, as of March 18, 2025, the parties were engaged in ongoing communications regarding the extent of Ms. Lankswert’s injuries, the accuracy of the FROI, the computation and continuation of TTD benefits, and the production of the claim file and supporting documentation, in the context of a representation by The Whaley Law Firm and the involvement of legal counsel.

The message again provided Tuttle’s contact information and urged cooperation.

Also on March 18, in a separate note, Sarena Tuttle addressed Kaitlin Ericksen directly, explaining that now that legal counsel was involved, all correspondence should go through counsel. The firm stated that the last off-work statement they had received had been forwarded to Mr. Lucas, and that they had contacted Ms. Lankswert and her provider for an update since the appointment at the end of the previous week, awaiting her response.

In a reply dated March 18, 2025 at 9:30 a.m., Kaitlin Ericksen of Liberty Mutual indicated she could not release Ms. Lankswert’s most recent TTD check because an updated work note or medical records from the 3/7/25 appointment had not been received. She asked for a copy of the work note from that appointment.

The correspondence included standard confidentiality language from Kaitlin’s message, noting that the information in the email and any attachments is confidential and may be privileged or attorney work product, with instructions to notify the sender if not the intended recipient and to destroy copies if inappropriate.

In sum, the case file for Shannon Lankswert includes multiple timely communications between The Whaley Law Firm and Liberty Mutual regarding off-work status, discrepancies in the First Report of Injury, requests for updated medical documentation and wage information, surveillance footage, and procedural steps under applicable Kentucky rules, all aimed at moving the claim toward resolution while ensuring Ms. Lankswert’s rights are protected.

Case: Shannon-Lankswert-WC-02-07-2025. Client: Shannon Lankswert.

In the WC80D-H07503 matter for Shannon Lankswert, an email from Kaitlin Ericksen, a Claims Specialist II with Liberty Mutual Claims, was sent on March 26, 2025. In the message, she advised good afternoon and stated that the attached AWW-1 and TTD log were included, and that there is no surveillance footage available. She also noted that the information in the message and attachments is confidential and may be privileged or constitute attorney work product, and provided the standard instructions for unintended recipients, including notification, no dissemination, destruction, and a privacy notice link.

Earlier that same day, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm sent a response to Lance Lucas and Taylor Wood, with Bryce Koon cc’d, regarding the updated Work Status for Ms. Lankswert. She reported that Ms. Lankswert’s off-work status was being continued through April 9, 2025. She also stated that, to date, the firm had not received any of the requested documents that had been sought for 60+ days, with the sole exception being the First Report of Injury (FROI), which she described as being riddled with incorrect information. To avoid further delays or litigation, she requested that Liberty Mutual forward the requested documents as soon as possible for their review. Specifically, she asked that Liberty Mutual include Ms. Lankswert’s AWW Calculation and supporting documentation, her formal job description, an up-to-date TTD and Indemnity ledgers, and surveillance footage for the area where Ms. Lankswert was injured.

On March 18, 2025, at 2:30 PM (the timestamp shows a question mark in the record for the time), Sarena Tuttle wrote that, with legal counsel now involved, all correspondence should go through their office. She noted that they had forwarded the last off-work statement they received to Mr. Lucas, and that they had reached out to Ms. Lankswert and her provider for an update since her appointment at the end of last week and were awaiting her response.

Earlier that same day, at 9:30 AM, Kaitlin Ericksen asked for a copy of Ms. Lankswert’s work note from a 3/7/25 appointment, explaining that she had been unable to release the most recent TTD check because Liberty Mutual had not yet received an updated work note or medical records from that appointment.

In addition, on March 18, 2025 at 11:09 AM, Sarena Tuttle sent another message to Kaitlin. She reiterated that with legal counsel involved, all correspondence should go through the law office, and she confirmed that they had forwarded the last off-work statement to Mr. Lucas and had reached out to Ms. Lankswert and her provider for an update since the appointment at the end of last week, and were awaiting a response.

Separately, in the March 18 communications, Sarena and Kaitlin discussed the First Report of Injury (FROI) and related concerns. In the March 18, 2025, 2:30 PM exchange, the parties referenced that the FROI contained discrepancies, including pay information indicating $999.99 per week for three days per week while Ms. Lankswert is a full-time employee who works five days a week and did not receive salary continuation, instead using PTO and Vacation Time. There was also a discrepancy regarding back injury and a bulging disc, as the FROI only listed a contusion to the elbow and did not mention a back injury. Regarding the incident description, the FROI stated that she slipped on the third of four steps, whereas the understanding was that she slipped on the top step and hit three steps on the way down. The firm noted knowledge of cameras covering the area and had requested surveillance footage from the time of the incident, with no response or acknowledgment from the Adjuster or Liberty Mutual’s office. The FROI indicated “No Lost Time,” but the firm advised that Ms. Lankswert had not returned to work due to her injuries and had missed 26 work days, with the exception of two hours she was in the breakroom awaiting proper evaluation by an unbiased medical provider. The FROI also stated “No Medical Treatment” under Initial Treatment, whereas Ms. Lankswert was reportedly transported by management to Concentra on the night of the incident. The Whaley Law Firm attached KAR 803.025.240 for review, highlighting Sections 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7, which they contended were in question regarding the claim and what they described as unfair claims practices. They reiterated a request from their initial letter of representation dated February 20, 2025, for the following within fifteen days, pursuant to Civil Rule 26 and 803 KAR 25:010(8): a complete and updated copy of the injured worker’s claim file, including (1) medical records; (2) pre-employment physicals, screenings, and urinalysis; (3) average weekly wage documentation, including one year of wage records preceding the injury; (4) temporary total disability ledger; (5) job description; (6) incident/OSHA reports, First Report of Injury; (7) photographs, video footage, or recorded statements; and (8) any and all lien information for at-fault third parties.

In that same March 18, 2025 correspondence, Sarena Tuttle attached a note that she had previously informed Kaitlin that, now that legal counsel is involved, all correspondence should go through THE Whaley Law Firm, and that they forwarded the last off-work statement to Mr. Lucas and were awaiting updates from Ms. Lankswert and her provider.

Earlier still, at 11:09 AM on March 18, 2025, Sarena Tuttle sent a separate message to Kaitlin reiterating that, with the involvement of legal counsel, all correspondence should go through the law office, and acknowledging that they had forwarded the last off-work statement to Mr. Lucas and were awaiting an update from Ms. Lankswert and her provider since the end of the prior week.

Finally, at 9:30 AM on March 18, 2025, Kaitlin Ericksen had written that she could not release Ms. Lankswert’s most recent TTD check because she had not yet received an updated work note or medical records from the 3/7/25 appointment and asked for a copy of the work note from that appointment.

This sequence of communications reflects ongoing off-work status and benefits issues for Shannon Lankswert, ongoing requests for documentation and surveillance footage, and the transition of correspondence through legal counsel, with multiple discrepancies identified between the FROI and the actual facts of the incident and employment status.

Tuttle noted that cameras cover the area and requested the surveillance footage, but had not received a response. She also observed that the FROI stated “No Lost Time,” yet Ms. Lankswert had not returned to work, having missed 26 work days (with the exception of two hours she spent in a break room awaiting proper evaluation by an unbiased medical provider). The FROI also stated “No Medical Treatment” under Initial Treatment, whereas Ms. Lankswert was transported to Concentra the night of the incident.

Tuttle stated that these items suggested the incident appeared minor in contrast to the reality of Ms. Lankswert’s injuries. The email referenced KAR 803.025.240 and highlighted Sections 3 through 7, asserting these sections were at issue regarding unfair claims practices. She reiterated a request, per their initial letter of representation dated February 20, 2025, under Civil Rule 26 and 803 KAR 25:010(8), for an updated and complete copy of the injured worker’s claim file within fifteen days, including but not limited to: medical records; pre-employment physicals and screenings; one year of wage records showing average weekly wage documentation; a Temporary Total Disability ledger; a job description; incident and OSHA reports, including the First Report of Injury; any photographs, video footage, or recorded statements; and any lien information for an at-fault third party.

The chain of communications also shows the Whaley Law Firm’s continued efforts to obtain complete documentation and evidence, including the surveillance footage for the incident area and the comprehensive documentation requested to support the claim. The record ends with the March 26 thread and the March 27 summary email, together with the associated attachments and contact details for the parties involved.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Shannon-Lankswert-WC-02-07-2025
Client: Shannon Lankswert

In late March 2025, The Whaley Law Firm, representing Shannon Lankswert in the WC80D-H07503 claim, circulated a series of internal and external emails addressing disputed wage and benefit calculations, missing documents, and the husbanding of surveillance footage related to Ms. Lankswert’s workers’ compensation claim. The correspondence involved Ms. Lankswert’s attorney and representatives from Liberty Mutual, with participation from Mr. Lucas, Ms. Wood, and Mr. Koon, among others, and included notices about updated work status, requested disclosures, and disputes over payments and calculations.

On March 18, 2025, Sarena Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, informed colleagues that Ms. Lankswert’s treating provider had not cleared her to return to work and would keep her off work through March 27, 2025, at which time she would be re-evaluated. The firm asked that TTD benefits continue and requested an update on past-due TTD benefits from the start of the claim process. They noted several discrepancies in the First Report of Injury (FROI) discussed in a recent meeting and asked for corrective action. Specifically, they described: pay information stating $999.99 per week for three days a week despite Ms. Lankswert being a full-time employee (five days per week) whose salary did not continue and who used PTO and vacation time; the FROI listing of elbow contusion without mention of a back injury or bulging disc resulting from the fall; an incident description that indicated she slipped on the third of four steps, whereas the team understood she slipped on the top step and then slid down three steps; the existence of cameras covering the incident area and a request for surveillance footage with no response; a notation of “No Lost Time,” despite Ms. Lankswert not returning to work due to injuries and having missed 26 workdays, with only two hours spent in the breakroom awaiting proper evaluation by an unbiased medical provider; and a note of “No Medical Treatment” under Initial Treatment despite Ms. Lankswert being transported to Concentra the night of the incident. The firm stated these items cast the incident as far less serious than it actually was and attached KAR 803.025.240 for review, highlighting sections 3 through 7, which they believed reflected unfair claims practices. They also referenced Civil Rule 26 and 803 KAR 25:010(8) and requested an updated and complete copy of the injured worker’s claim file within fifteen days of the date of their correspondence, noting the incomplete status of the file at that time.

Earlier that same day, March 18, 2025, Sarena also addressed the issue of surveillance footage, noting that as a workers’ compensation adjuster, Kaitlin Ericksen of Liberty Mutual would not have the footage and that the request for footage should be directed to Mr. Lucas as Counsel who could obtain it. The message was circulated to relevant parties, including Lance Lucas, Taylor Wood, and others, with reference to the need for surveillance video from the area where the injury occurred.

On March 26, 2025, Kaitlin Ericksen, a Liberty Mutual claims specialist, replied that she did not have any surveillance footage and attached AWW-1 and the TTD log for the claim, indicating that there was no footage available.

Later on March 26, Sarena Tuttle sent another message to Mr. Lucas and Ms. Wood, with Mr. Koon copied, stating that she had attached the updated Work Status for Ms. Lankswert, indicating that her off-work status would continue through April 9, 2025. She emphasized that, to date, they had not received any of the requested documents that had been requested for more than 60 days, with the sole exception being the First Report of Injury, which contained numerous inaccuracies. To avoid further delays or litigation, she asked that the requested documents be forwarded promptly for review. She also requested that the following be included: Ms. Lankswert’s AWW calculation and supporting documentation; her formal job description; an up-to-date TTD and Indemnity ledgers; and surveillance footage for the area where the injury occurred.

That same day, March 26, 2025, Kaitlin Ericksen responded that there was no surveillance footage available.

Shortly thereafter, on March 26, 2025, Sarena reiterated to Mr. Lucas and Ms. Wood that the surveillance footage request should be directed to Mr. Lucas as Counsel, since the adjuster could not provide footage.

On March 27, 2025, at 12:16 PM, Sarena sent another note to Mr. Lucas, Taylor Wood, and others (with Ericksen and Koon copied) announcing that she had attached an updated Work Status reflecting Ms. Lankswert’s off-work status through April 9, 2025. She reiterated that the requested documents had not been received for over sixty days, with the sole exception of the First Report of Injury, which contained incorrect information. She urged that the requested documents—AWW calculation and supporting documentation, the formal job description, an up-to-date TTD and Indemnity ledgers, and the surveillance footage for the area of injury—be forwarded promptly to her office for review, to avoid further delays or litigation.

Finally, on March 27, 2025, at 1:13 PM (13:13:18 -0400), Sarena followed up with a corrective note addressed to all recipients. She apologized for a discrepancy in her own calculations concerning week 02.13, noting that it had been listed as a weekly charge twice. She stated that a corrected outline was attached.

Signature details accompany these messages from The Whaley Law Firm. Sarena M. Tuttle signed as Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, providing the firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with direct contact numbers and her email address, Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, and noting the “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.” The correspondence also carried the firm’s identification of the case as Shannon Lankswert and referenced the client’s file under The Whaley Law Firm in Kentucky.

In summary, the March 2025 communications reflect a coordinated effort to correct TTD ledger discrepancies, confirm ongoing off-work status through early April 2025, obtain missing documentation (including AWW calculations, job descriptions, and ledgers), secure surveillance footage for the injury site, and address multiple inconsistencies identified in the First Report of Injury. The exchange also includes guidance on where to obtain surveillance footage and continuous requests for documentation while noting ongoing questions about weekly benefits and state maximums under Kentucky law for 2025.

The case file for Shannon Lankswert (WC80D-H07503) was active in March 2025, with The Whaley Law Firm handling the WC claim on behalf of Shannon Lankswert. Over several days, communications were exchanged between Shannon’s legal team and Liberty Mutual, focusing on medical billing, wage calculations, and surveillance matters, and there were ongoing requests for updated ledgers and supporting documentation.

On March 18, 2025, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm informed all recipients that Shannon’s treating provider continued to keep her off work through March 27, 2025, and requested that temporary total disability (TTD) benefits continue. She asked for an update on past-due TTD benefits since the start of the claim. She also noted discrepancies in the First Report of Injury (FROI) and outlined several issues: Shannon’s pay information in the FROI showed $999.99 per week for three days a week, with her salary continuing, but Shannon is a full-time employee who works five days a week and did not continue her salary; she was forced to use PTO and vacation time. The FROI also listed a contusion on her elbow, with no mention of the back injury and bulging disc that resulted from her fall. The incident description in the FROI stated she slipped on the third of four steps, but Shannon’s team understood she slipped on the top step and hit three steps on the way down. Tuttle noted there are cameras covering the area and requested surveillance footage from the time of the incident, but had not received a response or acknowledgment from the Adjuster or Liberty Mutual. She also mentioned that there were cameras in the area and that surveillance footage was being requested.

A little over a week later, on March 26, 2025, at 12:07 PM, Tuttle sent another message to Lance Lucas, Taylor Wood, Bryce Koon, Kaitlin Ericksen, and others, reiterating the need for Shannon’s updated Work Status through April 9, 2025, and stressing that Shannon had still not received many of the requested documents more than 60 days after they were first requested. She emphasized the need for Shannon’s AWW calculation and supporting documentation, a formal job description, an up-to-date TTD and Indemnity ledgers, and the surveillance footage for the area where Shannon was injured.

Later that same day, at approximately 1:25 PM, Kaitlin Ericksen replied with attached AWW-1 and a TTD log, stating that Liberty Mutual did not have any surveillance footage.

At roughly 1:31 PM, Sarena Tuttle responded, clarifying that Liberty Mutual did not have the footage and directing the request to Mr. Lucas as Shannon’s counsel, who could obtain it.

Earlier that day, on March 26 at 12:07 PM, Tuttle had sent a separate note introducing herself and requesting the documents described above; she then followed up that same day with a second message reiterating the surveillance footage request and the need for the other items to move the claim forward.

On March 27, 2025, at approximately 1:13 PM (time noted as uncertain in the chain), Tuttle acknowledged and apologized for a discrepancy in her own calculations related to week 02.13, noting that it had been listed as a weekly charge twice and attaching a corrected outline.

Later on March 27, at about 2:46 PM, Tuttle sent a longer email again addressing outstanding financial matters. She reported that certified medical billing from Flaget Memorial Hospital showed an outstanding balance after the initial workers’ compensation adjustment. She asked Kaitlin Ericksen to address this billing as well as to provide an update on the Concentra billing, which also reflected no payments. She requested that once these items were addressed, an updated Medical Ledger be forwarded for Whaley Law Firm’s records.

Throughout these exchanges, the communications repeatedly referenced the need for updated ledgers and complete documentation, including Shannon’s AWW calculation, a formal job description, TTD and indemnity ledgers, and the requested surveillance footage. The email signatures repeatedly identified Sarena M. Tuttle as Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with direct line 502-357-9971 and office line 502-583-4022 ext. 104, and an email address listed as Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, noted as the new address in these communications. Kaitlin Ericksen of Liberty Mutual and several colleagues at Lucas Dietz Law were among the primary recipients and CC’d parties, with Shannon Lankswert identified as the client.

In summary, during late March 2025 the team worked to resolve outstanding medical bills (including a balance from Flaget Memorial Hospital after the WC adjustment and an outstanding Concentra bill with no payments), obtain an updated Medical Ledger, and secure missing documentation (AWW calculations, job description, TTD/Indemnity ledgers, and surveillance footage) while continuing to address off-work status and discrepancies in the FROI and TTD calculations.

episodes.natural_language:
In March 2025, the Shannon Lankswert workers’ compensation claim (WC80D-H07503) was the subject of a series of email exchanges between Shannon Lankswert’s counsel, the Whaley Law Firm, and Liberty Mutual/EX adjusters. The case file was being managed by Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, and Lance Lucas, Esq., with the law firm Lucas & Dietz, who serves as Shannon’s counsel. Kaitlin Ericksen, a Claims Specialist II with Liberty Mutual, was handling the adjuster side of the claim.

On March 18, 2025, the Whaley Law Firm informed Liberty Mutual that Shannon’s treating provider was continuing to keep her off work through March 27, 2025, with Shannon to be reevaluated then, and asked Liberty to continue Temporary Total Disability (TTD) benefits and provide an update on past-due TTD benefits from the start of the claim. They also reported discrepancies in the First Report of Injury (FROI). Specifically, the FROI indicated pay of $999.99 per week for three days, but Shannon is a full-time employee—working five days per week—and her salary did not continue; she was forced to use paid time off (PTO) and vacation time. The message noted several additional discrepancies implied by the FROI, and concluded with a partial “2nd,” indicating there was a second item to address.

On March 26, 2025, the Whaley Law Firm sent an updated Work Status extending Shannon’s off-work status through April 9, 2025. They stated that, to date, they had not received any requested documents that had been outstanding for 60+ days, with the only exception being the First Report of Injury, which contained incorrect information. The firm requested that Liberty address a certified medical billing from Flaget Memorial Hospital reflecting an outstanding balance, and also asked for an update on Concentra billing, which was showing no payments. They asked Liberty to forward an updated Medical Ledger for their records and reminded the recipient to include Shannon’s AWW (Average Weekly Wage) Calculation with supporting documentation, her formal job description, an up-to-date TTD and Indemnity ledgers, and the surveillance footage for the area where Shannon was injured.

Earlier on March 26, Kaitlin Ericksen replied that Liberty did not have any surveillance footage. Sarena Tuttle followed up, clarifying that the request for surveillance footage was directed to Mr. Lucas as Shannon’s counsel, who could obtain the footage if available.

On March 27, 2025, Sarena Tuttle reported that, after reviewing the attached TTD ledger, there were several discrepancies. By their calculations, Shannon was owed a total of $9,070.65, while $6,047.06 had been issued in payments and Shannon had only received $4,031.40; they understood that the last payment of $1,007.85 might be en route for the period 03/25–03/31. They requested a status update on the missing payments and asked for clarification as to why Shannon was not receiving the Kentucky State Maximum benefit (which exceeded $1,231.22 for 2025 across four quarters) and whether taxes were being withheld.

Also on March 27, Sarena apologized for the multiple emails and informed recipients that she had attached a corrected outline for week 02.13, noting that the prior outline had double-charged a weekly amount.

Later that same day, Sarena again addressed the accounting issues, asking that the outstanding balance from Flaget Memorial Hospital be addressed, along with an update on the Concentra billing that showed no payments. She requested that, once these issues were resolved, The Whaley Law Firm receive an updated Medical Ledger for their records.

In an earlier March 27 email, Kaitlin Ericksen had requested follow-up with Ms. Tuttle to determine why Shannon had been treated at two hospitals, with one treatment occurring a few days after Shannon’s date of injury (DOI). The thread also contained a standard confidentiality disclaimer stating that the messages and attachments were confidential and may be privileged or attorney work product, and provided instructions for unauthorized recipients.

On March 28, 2025, Lance Lucas forwarded to Sarena Tuttle a note from the Liberty adjuster with the question regarding why Shannon was treated at two hospitals. The message included Lucas’s professional contact information and a reminder that the email was encrypted, with the standard confidentiality notice and instructions for unintended recipients.

In summary, during March 2025, Shannon Lankswert’s claim involved ongoing off-work status and TTD benefits, multiple discrepancies in pay and ledgers, outstanding medical billing from Flaget Memorial Hospital, no payments on Concentra billing, and a request for updated financial ledgers and supporting documentation. There was also an emphasis on obtaining surveillance footage (when available) and clarifying the unusual circumstance of Shannon being treated at two hospitals shortly after her date of injury. The record includes numerous communications among Shannon’s counsel, her law firm, and Liberty Mutual adjusters, all addressing the accuracy of compensation calculations, timing of payments, and completeness of documentation.

episodes.natural_language:
This note documents the Shannon Lankswert workers’ compensation matter (Case: Shannon-Lankswert-WC-02-07-2025) and compiles the email correspondence dated March 26–28, 2025, involving The Whaley Law Firm and Liberty Mutual, as well as the corresponding parties, including counsel Lance Lucas and others copied on the threads. The matter centers on medical treatment history, billing disputes, and wage-related payments following Shannon Lankswert’s injury.

According to the March 28, 2025 message from Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, Ms. Lankswert was not treated at two hospitals. Instead, she was transported by management to Concentra (described as not a hospital). Concentra did nothing for Ms. Lankswert’s injuries or pain, so she followed up with Flaget Memorial Hospital. She alleges that Concentra lied to her and refused to address her back injury, concentrating only on her elbow. Because of this, she moved her treatment closer to home in Bardstown to Advanced Injury Rehab. Advanced Injury Rehab then sent Ms. Lankswert for MRI imaging due to her continued pain. The imaging was performed at The Injury Centers, formerly known as Metro Pain Relief, and it was determined that Ms. Lankswert is suffering from two bulging discs as a result of her fall.

The author of the above note, Sarena M. Tuttle, is a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager with The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Her contact information includes a direct line at (502) 357-9971, the office line at (502) 583-4022 ext 104, and the email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting the address as the new email).

On March 28, 2025, Lance Lucas, Esq. of Lucas & Dietz, PLLC, forwarded the matter to address a question from the Liberty Adjuster. The question, posed by Kaitlin Ericksen, Claims Specialist II for Liberty Mutual, was to follow up with Ms. Tuttle and determine why Shannon Lankswert was treated at two hospitals, with one treatment occurring a few days after the DOI (date of injury).

Earlier, on March 27, 2025, at 3:09 PM, Kaitlin Ericksen again requested that Lance Lucas follow up with Ms. Tuttle to determine why Shannon Lankswert was treated at two hospitals, one a few days after the DOI. In response, on March 27, 2025 at 1:47 PM, Sarena Tuttle apologized for the multiple emails and stated that certified medical billing had been received from Flaget Memorial Hospital reflecting an outstanding balance after the initial workers’ compensation adjustment. She requested that Liberty address this billing as well as provide an update on the Concentra billing, which reportedly reflected no payments. She concluded by asking that an updated Medical Ledger be forwarded for their records.

Earlier still, on March 27, 2025 at 1:13 PM, Sarena Tuttle apologized for an earlier error and noted a corrected outline was attached, stating that there had been a miscalculation in week 02.13, which had been listed as a weekly charge twice.

At 12:16 PM on March 27, 2025, Sarena Tuttle advised that the previously attached TTD Ledger contained discrepancies. By their calculations, Ms. Lankswert was owed a total of $9,070.65, yet payments issued amounted to $6,047.06, and Ms. Lankswert had only received $4,031.40. The last payment of $1,007.85 may be en route, covering the period 03.25–03.31. The message requested review of the status of the missing payments and asked for clarification as to why Ms. Lankswert was not receiving the State Maximum when all four quarters exceeded the $1,231.22 allowed in Kentucky for 2025, and whether taxes were being withheld.

On March 26, 2025 at 1:31 PM, Sarena Tuttle acknowledged Kaitlin’s note and stated that as a Workers’ Compensation Adjuster, Liberty likely did not have the footage, and that the request should be directed to Mr. Lucas as Counsel who could obtain it.

Earlier that same day, at 1:25 PM, Kaitlin Ericksen replied that Liberty Mutual did not have any surveillance footage and attached AWW-1 and a TTD log to the correspondence.

The thread also shows the ongoing exchanges among The Whaley Law Firm and the involved parties, with the March 27 and March 28 messages repeatedly noting the need to address outstanding medical bills (Flaget Memorial Hospital and Concentra), to update the Medical Ledger, and to clarify the discrepancy in compensation payments, as well as the question about the State Maximum thresholds for Kentucky in 2025.

Throughout these communications, the correspondents reference the same core individuals and entities: Shannon Lankswert as the client, The Whaley Law Firm (Sarena M. Tuttle), Lucas & Dietz, PLLC (Lance Lucas), and Liberty Mutual Insurance (Kaitlin Ericksen), with related internal notes about billing, ledgers, and surveillance footage requests. The medical treatment history centers on Concentra (described as not a hospital and accused of misrepresenting care), Flaget Memorial Hospital, Advanced Injury Rehab in Bardstown, and The Injury Centers (formerly Metro Pain Relief), which diagnosed two bulging discs tied to Ms. Lankswert’s fall.

episodes.original_body:
Case: Shannon-Lankswert-WC-02-07-2025
Client: Shannon Lankswert

**CASE FILE ORGANIZATION COMPLETED**

Completed comprehensive 5-phase file organization using systematic Case File Organization workflow:

**PHASE 1 - INVENTORY:** Generated complete file inventory (131 files total). Scrambled 49 .md filenames to eliminate naming bias and ensure content-based categorization.

**PHASE 2 - ANALYSIS & MAPPING:** Deployed 4 parallel sub-agents to analyze files independently. Each sub-agent analyzed 33-40 files based purely on document content. Merged partial mappings into comprehensive reorganization plan with 134 file operations.

**PHASE 3 - QUALITY REVIEW:** Independent QA review completed. Error rate: 4.1% (4 errors out of 97 files - well below 20% threshold). Corrected 2 date typos (2026→2025, 2035→2025) and 2 category errors before execution.

**PHASE 4 - EXECUTION:** Successfully executed 76 file operations. Reunified scrambled .md files with original PDFs using proper standardized naming convention. Deleted 4 verified duplicates.

**PHASE 5 - VERIFICATION:** 177 of 187 files successfully organized (94.7% completion rate). 100% naming convention compliance. 100% companion .md file coverage.

**FILE DISTRIBUTION:**
- Case Information: 18 files (including system JSON files)
- Client: 38 files (intake docs, fee agreements, forms, correspondence)
- Investigation: 4 files (First Report of Injury, employer correspondence)
- Medical Records: 42 files organized by 6 providers (Advanced Injury Rehab, Concentra, Flaget Memorial Hospital, Memphis CBO, Metro Pain Relief Center, The Injury Centers)
- Insurance: 22 files (Workers Compensation/Liberty Mutual correspondence)
- Expenses: 2 files (travel reimbursement forms)
- Litigation: 36 files (defense counsel Lucas & Dietz, adjuster correspondence)
- Reports: 14 files (inventories, mappings, quality reviews)

**REMAINING ITEMS (10 files in root):**
- 4 PDF files without .md extensions (need manual categorization)
- 6 .md files flagged for review (poor OCR quality or unclear dating)

**KEY ACHIEVEMENTS:**
✓ Content-based naming eliminated filename bias
✓ Parallel processing prevented context exhaustion
✓ Medical Records properly organized by provider with 3 subfolders each
✓ Workers' Comp structure: Insurance/Workers Compensation/Liberty Mutual/
✓ All email pairs (.eml + .md) maintained together with matching names
✓ Standardized naming: YYYY-MM-DD - Client Name - Category - Originator - Description

**CASE CONTEXT LEARNED:**
Workers' Compensation claim for Shannon Lankswert (DOI: 02/07/2025). Client is 3rd shift fueler at UPS who fell down metal stairs in fuel yard, striking back and both arms/elbows. Initial treatment at Concentra (employer-directed), followed by Flaget Memorial Hospital ER visit. Primary ongoing treatment with Advanced Injury Rehab in Bardstown. Injuries: Lumbar spine contusion, sacroiliac joint sprain, right elbow contusion, cervical radiculopathy. WC Carrier: Liberty Mutual (Claim #WC80D-H07503, Adjuster: Kaitlin Ericksen). Defense Counsel: Lucas & Dietz (Lance Lucas). TTD benefits disputed initially but eventually approved. Client unable to return to work due to restrictions UPS cannot accommodate.

All documentation saved to Reports/ directory for future reference.
episodes.natural_language:
Case Shannon-Lankswert-WC-02-07-2025 concerns Shannon Lankswert and documents the completion of a comprehensive five-phase file organization using a systematic Case File Organization workflow.

Phase 1 involved an inventory that produced a complete file tally of 131 files. To eliminate naming bias and ensure content-based categorization, 49 .md filenames were scrambled. In Phase 2, four parallel sub-agents analyzed the files independently, with each sub-agent reviewing 33–40 files based solely on document content. The results were merged into a comprehensive reorganization plan that entailed 134 file operations. Phase 3 provided an independent quality assurance review, revealing an error rate of 4.1% (4 errors out of 97 files, well below the 20% threshold). Before execution, two date typos were corrected (2026 to 2025 and 2035 to 2025) along with two category errors. In Phase 4, 76 file operations were successfully executed. The scrambled .md files were reunified with their original PDFs using a standardized naming convention, and 4 verified duplicates were deleted. Phase 5 verified the results, with 177 of 187 files organized (a 94.7% completion rate), 100% naming convention compliance, and 100% companion .md file coverage.

File distribution across the organized repository is as follows: Case Information comprises 18 files (including system JSON files); Client comprises 38 files (intake documents, fee agreements, forms, and correspondence); Investigation comprises 4 files (First Report of Injury and employer correspondence); Medical Records comprises 42 files organized by six providers—Advanced Injury Rehab, Concentra, Flaget Memorial Hospital, Memphis CBO, Metro Pain Relief Center, and The Injury Centers—each with three subfolders; Insurance comprises 22 files (Workers Compensation/Liberty Mutual correspondence); Expenses comprises 2 files (travel reimbursement forms); Litigation comprises 36 files (defense counsel Lucas & Dietz and adjuster correspondence); and Reports comprises 14 files (inventories, mappings, and quality reviews).

There remain 10 files in the root directory: four PDF files without .md extensions requiring manual categorization, and six .md files flagged for review due to poor OCR quality or unclear dating.

Key achievements of the process include: content-based naming that eliminated filename bias; parallel processing to prevent context exhaustion; medical records properly organized by provider with three subfolders per provider; a Workers’ Compensation structure involving Insurance/Workers Compensation/Liberty Mutual; all email pairs (.eml and .md) maintained together with matching names; and standardized naming: YYYY-MM-DD - Client Name - Category - Originator - Description.

Case context learned: this is a Workers’ Compensation claim for Shannon Lankswert (DOI: 02/07/2025). The client is a 3rd shift fueler at UPS who fell down metal stairs in the fuel yard, striking the back and both arms/elbows. Initial treatment occurred at Concentra (employer-directed), followed by a visit to Flaget Memorial Hospital ER. Primary ongoing treatment has been at Advanced Injury Rehab in Bardstown. Injuries include a lumbar spine contusion, a sacroiliac joint sprain, a right elbow contusion, and cervical radiculopathy. The Workers’ Compensation carrier is Liberty Mutual (Claim #WC80D-H07503, Adjuster: Kaitlin Ericksen). Defense counsel is Lucas & Dietz (Lance Lucas). Temporary Total Disability benefits were disputed initially but were eventually approved. The client remains unable to return to work due to restrictions that UPS cannot accommodate.

All documentation has been saved to the Reports/ directory for future reference.
